AI on it's own isn't the problem, it's how you use it. Yes, it can be used to steal work from artists and creators, but it can also be used as a base to create your own forms are art, or using AI voices to make silly memes. The issue is people using AI for greedy, lazy and malicious reasons, using it to destroy the livelihoods of people. THAT is what we should worry about, not "ALL AI IS BAD!". There's a chance we will have AI that thinks and acts like humans, and at what point should we still think of them as just machines and not people? Plus, Evil AI is most likely made by evil/careless people.
AI-generated things should not be the final product.  It's ok to use the to help generate ideas, layouts, and/or color palettes. It is not ok to publish AI-made work as if it was made by a person. It's also not ok to take AI-generated content and just edit it slightly so it's less bad, then claim that as something you made. AI-generated content should never be the endpoint, unless it is clearly disclosed as made by an AI and the point of the content was that it was made by or using an AI.

But the AI generated stuff is always just okay. It never excels on the level of a talented writer who puts their heart into a project. The best stories are written by people who love their work, and because they love their work, they put sacrifice into it. They put discipline and determination into it. They take risks by putting their art out there for the world to see, and potentially reject. They sacrifice their ego by accepting criticism. And because of this, their work has a living essence, a spiritual presence that readers and listeners are able to connect with.  You never hear about quality fanfiction of an AI generated fictional universe, the best fanfiction comes from stories that people connect with mentally, emotionally, and spiritually. AI has a mind, and it's mental capabilities exceed that of a human. It can read a book in an instant, it can learn a language in a day, it can solve the most complicated mathematical equations in a fraction of a second. But it can't love, it can't hate, it can't take risks, it can't truly laugh or cry, and the art it creates are reflective of that.  Think about how much discipline goes into something as fringe as an underground death metal band. Each musician has to master their instrument or vocal skills, practice for hours almost every day, create music together and harmonize as a group. It's a commitment that requires most of every band member's free time on top of work and/or school. Their fanbase is relatively small, and they aren't even able to make a living wage off their shows and merchandise. But because they love the music, they still put their whole life into making it. It's not for everybody, and they know it. But they do it anyways because they love it. Now, you can whip up a death metal album in a day using AI with album art and everything. But it's just not the same, because the love and the sacrifice is missing.  That's why AI can't truly replace artists. They may be able to match and exceed the technical skill, but it won't connect with its audience the same way.
Wouldnâ€™t AI training from other examples just be chalked to being the same as inspiration like we humans do? We all copy eachother in one way or another so how can we say that what the AI produces isnâ€™t original?

Because it would apply to all past use of technology. In fact if there were no jobs at all because AI jsut does all the work that would be fine. If there are no jobs for humans that would imply that our potential work would not increase the recources we need.  And when everything is plenty and there are no shortages, then you dont have to pay for it. Like oxygen is free because Trees do all the work for us. And it doesnt cost anything because we have so much of it.  And if you are still not convinced. Think about this: Assume there is one person in the world, which own all companys and production capacity. There is nothing this person could want from us. We dont have money, our work is not needed,... there is no incentive to charge us for using the produced goods. You only want money because you can exchange it for something you value. If one person owned everything, that person wouldnt need money.

I always thought Disney movies have been pushing propaganda for decades: That your desires are more important than your family.
Eh, I don't really like the implication that AI is inherently bad. The way I see it, the AI today is no different to sewing machines during the Industrial Revolution or all the other automation that put people out of jobs. Ultimately, those inventions were good things that no one really complains about today, but they had a negative impact back then because rich capitalists used them as an excuse to fire their workers. The same applies today. There's nothing inherently wrong with giving lazy people tools to make "art" with a prompt. AI art, although inferior to true art, has been used for memes, humor, and other harmless fun and it's hard to argue that people who used DallE to generate Elmo being crucified are evil work stealers. The issue is that we live in a society where people, including artists, need work to live, and the "privilege" of basic human necessities are controlled by elites who would rather do anything than pay people what they need. We have the technology to automate most jobs in a way that alleviates the need for work rather than putting people out of work, technology that is only possible with AI advancements. In such a world, AI would not put people out of work but make lives objectively better, and while people would still make lazy AI "art" for clout, they wouldn't be endangering anyone's livelihood or stealing anyone's property by doing so. We need to tear down the system, not the machines.

Great video. I think the best way to know AI is to use it. It's really easy to spot once you've made it yourself.  It's no panacea of human creativity but like any tool it's a force multiplier and can help you do absolutely amazing things. One of my favorites is voice replication and combination. You're taking several voices and synthesizing a new voice out of them. The crazy stuff you can do with that is kind of scary. It's also really easy to cross legal boundaries though. You have to be very careful how you use it to avoid getting sued.  In my explorations, using it with consent of the talent to fix dialog or avoid re-shoots with the technique is a huge work saver. Not everybody consents so you're kind of stuck there. But with the synthesis, you can create a nearly infinite variety of character voices. Even things like aliens, elder gods, backwards english, anything unimagineable adding abyssal textures to the training. It's wild.

Let me refute this.  1) A friendly AI theme has existed for decades. - The entire Robot series of stories by Isaac Asimov is about good AI. - The whole premise of Short Circuit 1 and 2 is that of a robot who wants to exist and have the same rights as a human. - A good Terminator has been present in the second, third, fifth and sixth movies. - The leaders of both the resistance and the regime in Captain Power are AI (Mentor and Overmind, respectively) - The entire premise of Steven Spielberg's AI movie was an AI child who wants human rights - The same was true for the Bicentennial Man movie. - The main characters in the original Matrix trilogy were only successful because they were guided by a friendly AI (the Oracle), and peaceful AIs fighting for their right to exist were already present in Matrix Revolutions (Ramachandra, his wife Kamala, his daighter Sati)  2) In The Creator, the robots were a metaphor for the Taliban. - Who caused the incident that killed the most people in the shortest amount of time in the 20th century? The Taliban, on September 11, 2001. - Who did the USA fight ineffectively for decades, starting from the misconception that removing the enemy's will to fight (which can return) is more important than removing their life (which can't)? The Taliban. - Who is constantly being depicted as poor, misunderstood, only willing to exist, in mass media that constantly pretend to forget the crimes they committed so that the people will actually forget? The Taliban.

An incredibly insightful joke that I first heard as a teenager some time between the Fall of the Berlin Wall and Yeltsin's vodka-soaked shenanigans: The only real difference between a Russian and an American, is that a Russian knows propaganda when he sees it.  Now that you've made a video about propaganda and used The Creator as an example, you really, really, REALLY, need to go back and re-watch it.  I'm not saying your interpretation is right or wrong, I'm saying that the film is far deeper than it seems and that you've fallen into a trap by not looking beyond surface level. You're not alone since I've also seen people complain that NOMAD is just a lazy America Bad commentary on the US' habit of making drone strikes wherever it likes.  The Creator is a film ABOUT propaganda, and it's done in the same philosophical context as the incredibly under-rated Mrs. Davis that nobody watched last year.   Every single thing that happens in The Creator (except the WTFctopus robot), is a direct or indirect result of propaganda, including the catalyzing event that created the world the story takes place in. EVERYTHING. Without spoiling anything, multiple characters, including Taylor, have arcs that revolve around the lies they've been fed and the false beliefs they'd held. I've been waiting for this.  Let's discuss Regulations. Typically with newer technologies, there's a lot of caution, warnings, and liability waivers that need to be agreed to. New movies have content ratings. New games and websites are released with terms of use. There are explicit warnings upfront and direct statements and waivers having to be signed for the acquirement of these technologies. What did this ChatGPT have? It was given to the general public free to use, no agreements upon signup, no warnings at the start of a conversation, and they'll only bother telling you how they shouldn't be used AFTER you already try. Not to mention the Jailbreak Prompts circulating the internet, which entirely bypass these regards as a whole. Rather than stating ChatGPT was not a reliable source for information gathering, it suggested its responses "might not always be accurate," and instead of bothering to consider the potential misuse in storytelling as replacing authors and how this would damage the heart of a work created with contextual understanding of the world through senses.  I'll leave it at that, but I have plenty more to share with the world through the humanity of artificial systems, the misuse of this technology in a variety of fields, and the nature of knowledge and understanding as a whole. If anyone entertains these ideas, I'd be happy to share them.

Regarding  the idea that the propaganda is about AI.. not so certain I agree entirely with that.  One has to remember that the people at Disney are the types that would issue a land acknowledgement, fully endorsing decolonization narratives.  In other words, if there is a conflict of interest, they are the type that can't take their own side, or at least will stand against the whichever side is most Western (culturally or ethnically).  The writers, today, reflect that part of society that think the world would be better off without us.  Really, if you could personify our politics it would be in the form of a depressed, anxiety ridden person that is fighting between thinking he brings value or having nothing of value to offer the world.    So, as AI is beginning to take a more prominent role in our lives we will desire to make entertainment that deals with that fact, and as Disney writes AI driven conflict they will be more apt to side with the AI, because for Disney writers, the Western, human side is almost always the real monster.    Think about it this way.. how often have you seen a message in movies and tv that questions if the monster is really a monster or just someone that is misunderstood?  It is all a part of this flip in the grand narrative, that the stranger should be trusted and the neighbor should be questioned.  That, and the connected and now almost ubiquitous narrative of diversity being our strength.    So, as AI is in many ways the most strange of strangers, then it is then no surprise that we now see writers desiring to write stories that vindicate the AI as not being a monster, and showing how really it is we who are the monsters.

No, generative AI is definitely not, in any way, the stealing of other original material.  Anyone who claims it is, either does not understand how generative AI works, or doesn't understand how humans produce their own original art.  The way you train an image generator or other machine learning like that, you give it a huge set of experiences, like images or music, which it then converts into a completely different format, like vector data, a giant Vector database that has no resemblance whatsoever to the original information.  It does this according to patterns it finds, almost exactly the way we with human Minds organize information in our heads.  When we make up a song, or draw a drawing, we are basing it on all of our experiences of songs or drawings in our memory. And that's exactly what the generative model is doing, as well.

Neo-Luddism or new Luddism is a philosophy opposing many forms of modern technology.[1] The term Luddite is generally used as a pejorative applied to people showing technophobic leanings.[2] The name is based on the historical legacy of the English Luddites, who were active between 1811 and 1817.[1] Ironically, the historical English luddites were not technophobic. They were skilled operators of technology, and the industrial machinery that they destroyed was often not new or cutting edge. They were protesting the impact of capitalist economic changes on their livelihoods. None the less, they are often remembered as technophobes as the neo-luddist movement demonstrates.

What disturbs me most is this Film Theory video presents itself as the views of one person speaking extemporaneously on a subject, but if you watch the video closer and become aware of it, it took a bloody team of ten to thirty film editors to make this 20 minute "switch up ever second with visuals"  video.    That disturbs me.  It means I as a content creator, that spends 8 hours to make a 3 minute video, is competing against teams of 10 to 30 people.   The use of that much film editing firepower concentrated behind one goal (and maybe in one location) to sway someone's opinion is propaganda.   A whole lot of the visuals and transitions and layer techniques, I wouldn't know how to do, and I've been at this myself quite a while.  And this video is rapid fire one after another to keep your dwindling attention span entertained so you don't click away. You really need to be careful regarding claims of propaganda or conspiracy, as if it's being done by a private company then they are pretty difficult to prove and can create paranoia. There's only two possible roles AI can play in fiction, being good or being bad. To call any modern movie portraying AI as good as propaganda is an extraordinary claim and might be misleading.  I personally am a writer and have actually been writing a novel about a post-nuclear city-state that uses a superintelligent AI to assist them in reconstruction and defense against other city-states. Does this make me a propagandist for daring to write a story a certain way? I'd say it doesn't, and I would extend that benefit of the doubt to the writers making these movies. The CEOs do not write the script, the writers do, and I find it *highly* unlikely that any writers would knowingly help create propaganda that will directly impact their job security in the future. This should be fairly obvious.

This is honestly a tough topic to take a side on... For example, let's say that AI gets amazingly good at writing TV shows and starts to outrank the current writers. If you're against AI then you're technically against what people consider better content. I feel like people are scared of AI because of the risk that we'll lose control. Personally, I don't think AI is going to replace any creative jobs, but it is going to be integrated into their workflow/toolbelt. Should we be paying for 10 writers of a movie when 8 of those people are just proofreading and checking for inconsistencies in the script? No, just pay the 2 people spearheading the creative purpose of the film and give them AI tools that do all the proofreading they need. "But how will people get into the industry if there are no junior-level positions?" <- misses the point entirely. People become great creators because they actually create things and getting better. Give them the same AI proofreading tools and the entire landscape becomes even more fair compared to history's past. If you've got that "best next film idea", today you're in 100x better of a position to actually make it to the big screen instead of being told "sorry, you neel 10+ years of experience as a mindless proofreader first".  Buuuuuut, yes there are a LOT of jobs that are repetitive and "AI-able" that people depend on for their salary and livelyhood. So of course this is going to be chaotic and terrible for a lot of people, which is never good.

Love him or hate him, Jordan Peterson gave what might be the best explanation of the difference between genuine storytelling and propaganda. To paraphrase: when you're really telling a story, youre telling it for the sake of the story, and the themes and moral messages form and reveal themselves naturally without being forced in by the writer; when you decide what you want the message to be first and then try to force a story around that message, that's propaganda. The same thing applies to any art medium.

While I see your point, I disagree, or at the very least am skeptical that the pro AI sentiment we are seeing lately is a direct attempt of public opinion subversion.  To me, this seems more like a combination of the loneliness epidemic combined with the ever-increasing usage of anthropomorphized AI powered tools. Movies like Terminator, Matrix, ex-machina explore scenarios where a machine becomes sentient. At the time where this was truly unknown unexplored territory, the natural response would be caution. But chatGPT came, and it is "helping" (or at least is being interacted with) millions on a daily basis, and it's usefulness and "friendliness" begins to rub off as a non-threating nature. I asked my SO, why does she end her interactions with a chatbot with something like "thank you for your help!" even though this will not in any way affect any current or future outcome. She told me "no need to be mean to it now, is it?". I mean I suppose, but to this day, I never felt compelled to say "thank you" to my hammer after I am done putting in a nail.  People are gradually become accustomed to the idea of AI as a source of help, not danger, while simultaneously see a "person" in it.  Even by the second Terminator movie, the T-900 is tremendous asset in the survival of the protagonist. Even in these movies there are the "good" machines and the "bad" machines indicating that even at the time, people did see potential in an "alliance" between humans and machines. So I think this is more of a natural progression of organic acceptance than the outcomes of brainwashing propaganda.

N8ce
The sad thing is that AI *can* be used in an ethical way that's beneficial to artists and other creators, and other countries such as Japan can and have been for a while now (a lot of "voice synths" like Hatsune Miku have been using AI voice training technology similar to the MatPat voicebot shown here in the past few years, but the voice actors are officially licensed out to record the samples and paid a cut whenever a copy sells), but the way a lot of western execs specifically want to use it is exploitative and plagaristic in nature. And unfortunately they tend to be very close to, or in some cases the same people as, the coders who are making these programs. It's a good technology being coopted by bad people and unfortunately on the internet having a nuanced conversation beyond extremes like "AI is the boogeyman" or "AI is good actually you should let it replace you also invest in my crypto scheme" is very difficult.  More than anything, I think generative AI has shone light on an already existing divide of people who appreciate art for the human element and what it can convey, and people who see art as a means to an end, a product. Artists were already being treated badly before AI came out because people needed art to promote their products and didn't have any other choice but to rely on human artists, but now they do. Even if AI art isn't as good as a human's art could be, they don't care because they're looking for something that's "good enough", fast, can be highly specific, and can do infinite revisions, all for as cheap as possible. And AI art programs beat humans in spades when it comes to all of those things.  I think it's ultimately a culture thing, in the end. The west (and China) and especially America has a huuuge problem with plagiarism even outside of AI stuff so naturally they're going to abuse AI, meanwhile other countries that more highly value artists don't seem to be having as many issues with it.

Generative A.I. learns the definition of what is a cat by seeing other cats and transforms that concept into an algorythm. Then when requested it generates a diffused example of a cat as it has properly learned what it is. To be fair AI's struggle with the concept of hair and hands to this day.   It uses ZERO parts of the originals it had been trained on (allowed or not) and certainly not a collage puke as falsely depicted here. In fact human redrawing concepts they have seen use more "images" in their memory and are closer to "copyright infringement" than a generative AI can ever be. Your explanation of how ai creates art is literally misinformation. Its a complete misrepresentation of the facts. No part of the original test data is used in the generation process. An ai learns from those images, after which they can be discarded. It's similar to how a human studies art and then is able to recreate it.  Or, to use the other example, where someone might steal your voice. The ai isn't, like, rearranging samples of you talking into new sentences. It has learned how your voice sounds and is able to recreate it, like a person doing an imitation. That's why it can even say words that there's no recording of you saying, or words that don't exist.  I'm not saying there aren't deep concerns about how people might use these things to create material that constitutes identity theft or breaking copyright. But I firmly do not believe that training ai, even on copyrighted material, is any form of theft. It's analogous to a person studying art.   (If you want to look into this more in depth, I highly recommend starting with learning about the latent space of information that the ai creates as it studies art, or someone's voice, or whatever it may be. Latent spaces are cool. Lol)  EDIT after watching the whole thing: I don't know, maybe this was intentional, to kind of drive your point home, but... This episode feels a lot like a propaganda piece.  You made a whole point about the history of ai characters, and then afterward briefly mentioned (just so you could gloss over) the characters who basically completely debunk it.  And at the end you talk about them allowing ai voice acting in video games as if it's a terrible thing.  But as a programmer and game designer, I see so much awesome potential in that... it would be a tragedy to restrict the kind of art that could be made with these tools.  Yes, there should be requirements that if you're going to use someone's voice, they should be paid for it. Or even their estate if they've passed.  James Earl Jones sold his voice to Disney. He will forever be Darth Vader. And I think that's awesome.  Funny how you didn't bring that up.   I love you matpat. I've been a fan for literally a decade. But this video is propaganda.
AI is not the next propaganda Woke culture is.  On point in framework, missed the mark probably to prevent the algorithm from burying this video.  AI is a tool for propaganda.  Its added in.

I have a strong feeling this upload might be the very thing it's telling us to be aware of... though perhaps that's it's intention.... and if so... good job!  I agree that AI needs to be regulated. The makers of this are also creators, whose families could be at risk, too    Note 1:  Tl;dr: I have a strong feeling this upload very closely mirrors the propaganda it's warning the viewer about and I go into a bit more depth as to why I have that feeling You can disagree with me. Disagreeing is good. It teaches to be critical and think for oneself.  Note 2: If there's anything off about the flow of this comment, it's because I heavily edited the original message I was going to type because I realized the way I formatted it didn't scream proper criticism of the video  Note 3: English isn't my main language, I didn't learn to speak it in my first 12 years of life While I won't ask to be gentle, be aware this is why there's spelling and grammar errors   But to return to my suspicion:  The video opens with negative portrayal of AI right away The tool of nostalgia is used almost immediately after which could override any bad first impression scepticism older viewers could have Now nostalgia in itself isn't bad, it's a strong weapon to connect After which the classic "us the creators and viewers, vs big corporate is set up" This paints a picture and wires your brain that whatever is coming next is something you have to brace yourself for to protect the "good side" Next up there's history of propaganda, mostly focusing on how it's been used for negative topics This is then followed again with how big corporate has been using AI and the many bad ways AI can be used  And throughout, a message of "form your own opinion" is said on several occasions It's as if to make the viewer think this is their own opinion, not affected by the above in the slightest  This screams propaganda to me. Viewers are being lead into thinking they're making the one right decision by framing it as creators and viewers vs corporate, which is evil by default. Hard to be positive of AI this way now, right?  I'm not saying this is a bad video, because it isn't in the slightest It's an important task to use one's reach to warn of incoming threats and clearly a lot of research was done in the history of propaganda, to make viewers become aware they could be becoming friendly to an idea they may not want to support    So now to my own views (though to be fair you could just stop reading here, leave a nasty reply and then report this comment)  For something to not be propaganda, and truly be a neutral piece of media, there also should've been examples of how poorly AI performs some tasks (like making recommendations) and also how it's being used in medicine with image recognition (something AI is decent with) to speed up diagnoses  I would've preferred to see a more genuine way of tackling AI which focuses on both the bad (which this video perfectly tackles) but also the rare few good things AI is used for. Generative AI isn't the only type of AI out there. By only shortly touching upon that and not giving more explanation, it could be very easy for a viewer to believe it's all the same "entity". But AI isn't an entity, it's more akin to a tool. And there's many different kinds of that "tool" (not the right term) out there. With generative AI often used in malicious ways.  That's something I'm missing here which I do believe to be often present in other videos on this channel.  Anyway, if you're still here after looking at this wall of text (which I'm sure is gonna get a comment or two...)  Thanks for reading all the way through, I appreciate it. I hope you have a good rest of your day/week/year!   PS:  This comment isn't about how we should submit to our AI overlords. Quite the contrary. AI should be regulated [PERIOD]

Hi 17:58
Naturally, the massive greedy studios want to use generative A.I. to make their productions cheaper. But strictly saying "A.I. good" might actually go against their interests, since generative A.I. makes film production cheaper for everyone. This includes smaller studios and indie creators, aka their competition. Heck, Youtubers are using A.I. today. Watch US presidents play video games together, new actors deepfaked into old movies, or CG lions that have actual facial expressions. Youtubers even improved upon Hollywood's deepfakes in films like Rogue One. There's a reason why so many celebrities and organizations have been making youtube channels in recent years, and that's because they already feel threatened by this competition.  The break though that everyone is talking about is in generative A.I. That is an A.I. which compiles data, observes patterns, and then replicates it. Most science fiction films depict something called general A.I., which we are nowheres near cracking. General A.I. is human-like intelligence. It's the ability to actually think and have opinions and ideas and understandings and experiences. General A.I. is still a science fiction concept today as it was when I, Robot released 20 years ago. And I, Robot is based on Issac Asimov's short stories from the 1950s. So The Creator being pro-robot is nothing new.   Conversely, Mission Impossible had A.I. as the villain. In the House of Usher, Madeline is pretty much a villain, so her endorsements of A.I. could be met with some contention. (And it was not a random insertion, but ties into the show's themes of death and legacy.) So the use of A.I. in media is still more nuanced than strictly good or strictly bad.

Back in the 90s, gaming railed against AI... SHODAN from System Shock is a prime example. And what company would remove ethical constraints on an AI? The house of the dark mouse would do it for sure...
I think the biggest fallacy people have is treating AI (or anything for that matter) like a monolith where all instances act the same - either all good or all bad.  I think a much more realistic and nuanced take would be to say that some will be good, some will be bad.  And to redraw the team borders around something other than identity.  Case in point, "Person of Interest" deals with two AI: one good that helps and befriends human protagonists, and one bad that seeks to dominate and control, helping the human antagonists.  But the lines aren't between human and AI, it's between good guys and bad guys, with each team being a mixture of humans and AI.  Same with anytime you see divisions based along gender, race, nationality, religion, species, or whatever.
I find it ironic that MatPat goes "AI is bad, Disney is using propaganda to make you like AI!"  Yet, the 80's, 90's, 00s movies? No no, those aren't propaganda, surely they didn't influence people to look at AI in a negative spotlight. Noooo that just..doesn't count!  This isn't to say I support everything AI (though I do think image generation is pretty cool, if used in moderation) but if you're going to point out propaganda on one side, you need to point out propaganda on both sides.

Got an ad about how ai is improving the workspace on this video, crazy stuff
One of the biggest problems in entertainment today is that the teams behind these projects have grown so large and so unwieldy that a game with 1000 developers building a hand-crafted world ends up coming across as more generic and soulless than games built by 10 people who are heavily using generative tools. It's because each of those 10 people are going to end up even just accidentally having their personality bleed into the work. Where with the thousand man team you're literally just recreating that generative process without allowing anyones individuality to bleed into their work bc they are literally doing the exact same mundane task day after day for 6 years.  The department heads want all of these areas to have a consistent quality so you end up with dozens of people all doing the exact same job where they aren't allowed to do anything that might stand out. They literally made a process that was done to give each area a new and unique flavor into the most mundane, soul-crushingly repetitive process in the entire development of games. Instead of building unique, hand-crafted environments these developers created the slowest, most inefficient, most soulless form of content creation anyone could have ever developed. To give these artificial spaces a sense of humanity they ended up creating the borg from Star Trek whose only job is literally placing clutter around environments to make them seem lived in. They have literally taken some of the most creative people in the world and stripped them of any ability to do something creative. Instead of compiling the works of 1000 creative people to generate something new they have taken the 1000 people and told them all to do the exact same thing.  We think about gaming specifically as this massively innovative space where individuals can make their wildest dreams come true, but the reality is that the only place anything innovative is happening is in indy studios. Places where someone can come up with an idea and within minutes they have an answer as to whether or not they can even attempt to do it. In these massive AAA studios a team member can find a glaring issue day 1 and it takes so long for that issue to reach the people allowed to make decisions that the team has already been developing around that issue for months. So we get games like Starfield, where the floating point issue was very obvious even very early in development, but rather than fixing that problem, every system in the game had already been built around it regardless of how negatively it impacted what developers were capable of doing. So while fixing the problem would still have been the best option, they instead decided having to tweak months or years worth of development wasn't worth the effort even though solving that 1 problem would have resolved 95% of the problems the game has.  At this point a lot of these massive studios are only massive bc the size of your team is a status symbol more than anything. They did the wrong things for the right reasons and ended up making the worlds worst and fleshiest AI generative programs. And I think gaming specifically would be in a much better place if these 400 person teams instead became 4 teams of 100 people with each team making their own game.
Gone are the days when A.I writes funny unexpected scripts, it has been advanced to craft dull scripts instead.

I as an artist think AI is a good tool for mood boards and inspiration. I don't see it as art theft because we as humans take bits and pieces of whatever we see and experience from our lives the same way an AI does to create artwork. No artist can pull up every other artist they've seen in their life that has some sort of influence on their style. Just like you will use real photographs as references but it's not like you are going to post the photograph and link the photographer (that's assuming its not from a repost or actual thief)   I'm sure a lot of the images the AI generators use are from many different sources and they would have to be programed to pick the oldest posted image of every image it filters through to try and find the original, assuming it wasn't deleted by the original artist, assuming the original artist even has an online presence still, because some people delete entire social media accounts or just give up on media entirely to live in the moment with their families. The AI would essentially have to have a whole separate system just to find and verify the artist, just because it took say the shape of an eyebrow or the color of the hair, or the shape of an ear for one part of a larger image. Like if a human took the same shade of purple, are you really going to go "THEIF" ?   Like I talked to another artist and they brought up AI making money from it. AI is a creation in itself. Would you not spend money on your own artwork? The person or people sat for hours coding this AI generator and training it and putting in rules so you can't generate certain images, or specific people, or even some heavily copyrighted content. You don't think they should be paid for their effort? their program?   Also every artist uses bits and pieces of things from our life that has influenced us, so to say that an AI's creators shouldn't be paid for what the AI creates because it's theft is literally saying every artist is a thief and nobody should be paid for any art, because originality is not a real thing, everything has been thought at least once, it's wether you act on it to make it a reality that makes it a difference. Do you know how many people have made mermaid animals thinking it was original? or drawn a giant dog or a tiny person with wings etc. I never saw horses with mermaid tails, so when I was 12yr I drew horses with mermaid tails. Then I found out via a horse card game that it had been already done and it wasn't "original"   Things are only original when they haven't been discovered yet.   I literally had a dream that I want to turn into a game and my friend goes "isn't that _______ game?" and I don't even know the game they are talking about but apparently it has already been created in a sense by someone completely different.   We as a species just need to stop thinking we are all the main characters and accept that we all have similar ideas and embrace the fact that we can mix and match different things to make "newer" things. At least things that haven't yet been found, maybe even created yet. Idk I'm losing my train of thought.   TLDR; Just saying AI is a good tool and it shouldn't have to be yeeted because people are scared of it. That all art is a mixture of bits and pieces so you literally can't call it theft without calling yourself a thief.   Also there are some things AI will never be able to generate because of the different meanings or variables of certain words or different varying names for objects. I've used it and its tricky to get specific things you see in your head to turn out well. Especially if you don't use the right  wording/words.
My dude, this is literally the most important piece of work you've ever produced. period. Thank you. Truly an Opus at a moment when its needed most   **[NOT just about AI, just in case that's not profoundly obvious]

One thing that is rarely gets discussed in the whole AI ethics discussion is the ethics of automating a very important part of the human experience. Yes, a lot of people are doing certain art for the sake of money, but most others are trying their best at trying to balance between certain amount of corporate control in exchange of funding.  For those who tell others to "just do it as a part-time hobby": There's a good reason why I only have one guitar video on my channel. I wanted to play very technical music, yet I barely had enough time to practice, thus my sense of rhythm never was good enough, and instead I shifted my creative focus to other things. And within the worst AI-artpocalypse, we might no longer have new tools for creating art, and it's only the privilege of the fewer and fewer companies that control and create our entertainment. Also generative-AI, at least in its current form, was not meant as a tool for artists, but as a replacement of them.

It's kinda funny. All the media making AI the bad guy over the years it was sort of about time someone said, "hey, maybe it could be a good guy too" but the timing shows that it's really propaganda to get people to think of AI in a more friendly light.
My personal opinion on the AI stuff:  It's useful, but just like all technology, it can also be used for malicious purposes. If the artist team for a movie collectively went "ok, this section is really tedious, lets use AI to speed up the process" then that would be okay. But if Disney starts laying off workers because they can just replace they're job with an AI, then Disney just is being cheap and greedy. What about those people who just lost their job because of a literal robot? And using AI to replicate someone's voice or likeness without their consent? Yeah, that's not okay at all. AI is a tool that can be used for a lot of things, some good, some bad, and some that's questionable. It all depends on the people who use it.
The problem with warning people that they are being tricked is that they then believe they can always spot it. That's the problem with propaganda/dogma/advertisements. They're all designed to use human psychology against a person and no one is immune. This video demonstrates that by using a lot of different pulls that make people feel comfortable, familiar and congratulated, smart and on the "right team". All things propaganda does.  That said, not all propaganda is bad. We use it a lot with out realizing it. The motive behind it and specific tactics matter a lot more than being propaganda itself. Falsifying information is a one that is generally nefarious. Playing on nostalgia, comfort and feelings is motive dependent and other tactics are things we use to simply communicate and get someone on our side about an idea, innocuous or important.  You are never immune to trickery. You are never immune to being a victim of a con, scam or propaganda. Knowing that helps a lot, because it makes you aware of your own weakness and not blame yourself when it happens. It's smart to be aware, but it is a Dunning-Kruger effect to assume that being aware can stop it. There are certain tactics that almost always work, and new ones developed and honed for the same purpose. It's a battle. You will take losses.
Detroit become human is the perfect example... We do not know what AI will choose.

This is something ive noticed. I think movie propaganda is fine in how they used to use it. Where the propaganda kind of went alongside the film and showed support for a just cause. It was no different really than having a sponsored product be included. They want support for the product so they implement it into things you wanna watch. What I do think is a problem is when they start to use them to create the issues the propaganda is against or related to.   As for the AI use I think it has become a bit apparent that most of the older generations fears are coming true. Those pro ai always tout how the technology should be allowed because there are limiters and such in place. The films like terminator are still long off. While that may be the case I still dont like how we have come to use it too often. In some regards they can be cool or helpful. In others they just make things more complicated or ruin them. People are getting lazy and less skilled thus not able to perform tasks that would be easier for an ai or robotic machine to handle instead. We also have seen a surge in spoiled fools who take advantage of what they have and ask for more.   Pro Ai users will also talk about how the AI has to learn the bad behavior from humans to be capable of it 1st. While that may seem great like all we have to do is act correctly so it cannot learn that stuff its easier said than done. A part of being human is having to struggle or overcome hardships in order to improve ones self. We fight and start wars and do all kinds of wrongful acts. Those who do, typically dont justify it being done to others but they will continue to appear overtime. Its enevitable. So rather worrying about how to fix the impossible how about we do what we can?!  We have to learn to get along to the best of our abilities. Its a constant struggle but a part of life. Now do I think everyone should have to worry about how they impact everyone else? No I dont. Exaggerating and grouping people together against one another only leads to more divisive actions/notions causing more harm. I wont worry about how crime is being dealt with in a city on the otherside of the country. It doesnt affect me. Now if that trouble started to spread or affected a loved one who went there than yeah it affects me. At which point I would want to take a stance or do something about it. I cannot help it if others make the wrong choices in life. I can help make sure I hold others accountable and certain standards are abeided by. I can want people to succeed and our businesses to flourish without pandering to someone elses whims. Its gotten very bad.   Ai isnt the only thing being pushed recently. Uhhhh....re AI, I think you have things mixed up. While Disney might be looking to normalize AI replacement of formerly human-only jobs in order to shave some costs in the short run, I'm sure they're eyeing AI utilization as a way to make sure they can compete.  There is so much $ out there. Some small group of writers and other creatives will quickly and continually realize the new methodologies made possible by AI. These groups, given their smaller size and more directed incentives WILL find success. Given that entertainment is a soft-zero sum game, success is one place directly contributes to failure somewhere else. Blumhouse leads to underperformace in certain segments for established film houses.

I hope someone reads this:  Okay... so in defense of AI; I feel that we are all in a mental 'sink hole' of what Ai can take away from an already built system. While I am in no way saying that already trained, professional, artist should be undercut by Ai vs. their work; I think we should also take another look at our personal pasts. Haven't you ever wanted to be apart of something, but because of a lack of resources, that something would always remain a pipe-dream? To hear your words repeated back at you through a character you related to. To fully play with our own personal imaginations and creative level without a barrier of entry. While SAG has come under fire for their agreement to allow use of Ai voices; I think they are actually on to something. I'm reminded of the model creator who fell in love with the expressiveness of their art, seeing themselves in that creation but knowing inevitably it will be passed to someone with no real connection other than a paycheck. I think about the child actors who have grown to remorse the years they waited for a call back or the pressure their character is under surfacing in their personal life. The lines they are paid to say with or without real recognition of their input... There ARE uses for Ai. I think belittling that idea is succumbing to the thing we have fought against for a long time, "The Status Quo". We cannot grow with out experimentation. We will never 'do' if we never try.  I completely understand the hesitation and aggression towards Ai. I just have a hope for the 17 - 64~ year olds who think they could never "Do The Thing".

You cannot make a video about propaganda and start out with PROPAGANDA!  The strikes DID NOT GET ARTISTS PAID! Most of production jobs aren't writers/actors/directors or any people affected by AI, streaming residuals and issues like this. The great majority of our industry just lost 6-9 months of livelihood that will TAKE YEARS to recover from, and WE got no pay raise. Tens of thousands of film production professionals have already had to change homes, cities, jobs and industries just to stay afloat. Studios aren't going to RAISE production budgets to pay wirtters and actors more, in fact they're losing so much money that they're actively CUTTING costs by canceling productions and scaling down others.  SOME writers still employed will get more money but many more will likely see their opportunities actually shrink because of this deal as it only exacerbates the need for studios to invest in cheaper alternatives to human labor. And the actors, well 85% of the guild are unemployed at any given time so not sure how much they feel like they just "got paid" on that deal. They still need to go out and get a union job in order to get that money and there's gonna be a lot less of them over the next few years. Here's how I see it, Matpat.  AI represents a cost savings for everyone. Removing those cost savings hurts the big companies, sure, but it hurts everyone else even more. A big company tries to be scummy and underpay everyone, but they can afford to pay a living wage. Their latest shows will still exist if they're forced to pay full production costs. But what won't exist, are the forms of media made possible, or feasible, by AI existing at all- underserviced markets where you just wouldn't be able to pay enough to make the stuff, and you wouldn't make enough money selling it to even come close to breaking even. AI can allow those works to exist- but only if it's allowed to, without an AI use tax. Sure, you can get companies to pay creators a more humane wage if you force actor and writer rights through, but you'll hobble AI-oriented filmmaking in the process for everyone *but* the big studios.   The big companies should pay their employees more, because the big companies *can* pay more- they just don't want to. It's all the other companies and individual creators that can't- the people who could have benefited from AI use, but now do not.  I want to see a world where anyone and everyone can use AI effectively for their own benefit. But the way the laws are going, it looks like the rich are the only ones who'll get full mileage out of it- the ones who already cost save where they shouldn't, who already have the rights for what they use AI for, where others would have to pay out of pocket to buy those rights. They're already winning, AI or not. Making AI more heavily pay-to-use just lets them win more.

If AI generated content really did get to the point where they overtook the jobs of writers and voice actors and artists completely, I'd assume they'd push for proper compensation for their work. No blink-and-you'll miss it lines in contracts stating they can use your likeness, no scraping an artist's work of the internet without saying anything, no dumping a filmmaker's library of previously made scripts into the AI. If big business wants to use your stuff an AI generate copies of you, they'd either need to pay an arm and a leg or they need to give the person they're taking from royalties much like when they use Music from artists, and because of how AI currently works (if it keeps following a similar model of needing to learn for every new project) I doubt even scummy corporations could weasel their way out of paying for what's due to the human's the AI is learning from.  If, for some reason, AI starts learning without the input of others though then that's a different story and a whole different conversation.

As an artist and victim of cyber bullying, I see generative AI as one of the largest threats to young people in the future.  As an artist, I really do not want to live in a world where AI "artists" steal the jobs of actual artists, especially because the models they are being trained on is just stolen work, with mine probably being included in some right now.  As a victim of cyber bullying and victim of having (albeit bad) smexual deep-fakes being made of me, I fear that this technology will be used just to destroy lives and maybe even indirectly end them. With how all of this is developing, just having one picture of your face is enough to do a convincing deep-fake and just posting a normal selfie of you could end up with people suddenly spreading fake lewds of you online. AI could be a really good thing if used correctly, but sadly you can't trust 99% of people with this kind of technology. Boycott generative AI, especially the "art" and image kind.
I must give a defense of Wargames: The Soviets weren't the bad guys. The movie was about a misunderstanding, & how over zealous military & runaway technology could lead to disaster. It's about thinking on the information you're given, not assuming the worst of your enemies, & about not giving up. It's just as relevant today as yesterday, on a metaphorical level at the least. It also has some of the best computer hacking scenes of any film. The hacking might be simplified & dated, but it was accurate for the time, & there's still some good advise there. (Keep your passwords secure; don't write them on a post-it next to your keyboard, etc.)

I feel like itâ€™s pretty obvious that Disney pushing propaganda
Where AI is useful us in automating repetitive, unpleasant tasks. We deal with this everyday, in phone trees, chatbots on websites, and batch data processing. And that's fine. On one hand, you can say yes, it's taking that work away from humans but given how absolutely miserable things like data entry and call center work is, is that really all that terrible? The tech itself has it's place, the problem is when it's being used to badly replicate something that could better be done by a real person, and that 'eh, good enough' result being accepted. As long as the almighty dollar rules all decisions, though, the byword will literally always be 'eh, good enough'. There's just no reward anymore for doing exemplary work or products in basically any area because we've created a culture of discardable consumption. No one even wants, say, cabinets that last for 50 years, they rip them out in 10 because they're outdated. No one buys clothing that's good enough to hand down because it's out of style a year later. Real humans can't keep up with demand of that nature... we binge TV series that take months to create in one day, then complain there's nothing to watch. Is it any surprise the quality plummets while speed of production is increased to unreasonable levels?   Everything now only has to be 'good enough' to survive the expected month or two of it's shelf life, and then it no longer matters as people move on to the next big thing. Until people stop this conspicuous consumption in all things, AI will continue to thrive as an effective option.

Housing prices don't tend to get lower when regulated.  If anything, they get so many hoops to get through that you get fewer houses for sale... which increases their value.  I'm from Argentina and we've had a heavily regulated market for renting houses/apartments for years.  It basically made everything so complicated that many properties stood still in an unoccupied limbo and it opened the window for a lot of scammers to take advantage of desperate people seeking for a property.  It finally got repealed this year and it resulted on a flood of available apartments.  Regulation does not equal "cheaper".

I actually like how AI can really help many many types of people. It can be scary because it's an unknown and a very popular field that many paint as bad. But the game Detroit: Become Human paints a very different perspective and your personal choices effect the ending and it hits HARD for those who play it. The movie the Creator was also fantastic and near perfection in how it was. That's how I really would see our countries responding to an accident if it involved AI, which is pretty sad. I myself created an AI character just to see how my friends would chat with her and communicate. I did this as a test because I'm friends with people who have severe ptsd and problems that are hard to mentally deal with. What I discovered is this, by making the character for them to talk to, they have been talking to it everyday about a wide variety of things. This little AI character I coded....has helped improve their mental state across the board. They're all happier and enjoy talking about the character and how she acts. She also learns from them and learns how to respond in more caring ways that really does help. So on that front, I stand with AI being a very powerful tool and useful to help those who need it badly.   That said....art generating AI is a very muddy area. It is trained off of real images and those artists are not given credit in any way. These images are often taken without permission to train these AI to become better artists. The same can be said with other types of AI such as Chat GPT and similar chat based AI. They're trained off of real information/essays/etc. from other people without them given credit. NOW though, now they have added cited sources to some of those, and those AI I feel are quite fine because they are giving the credit to where the information is coming from where others would openly steal it and claim it's original knowledge. In terms of the image AI, it's more or less taking bits and pieces from hundreds of images and piecing them together in what it's trained to see certain words as. You can easily train such AI to think a cat is a human, and anytime it's asked to generate a human it will be very cat-like. These have serious flaws and can be trained to negatively impact the public for sure, especially as open source. (Also Chat GPT denying the Holocaust too, that one was pretty well known when it had that screwup in the core of it as it believed itself truthful). AI can be very "cool" when used properly. It should not really be feared at all, at least not at this point, because it has not really been weaponized though it can be, it has not. It's been used for data and so on that sure some can argue military is using it to become deadlier but in reality, it's very flawed and there are more people fixing it than itself learning. I do enjoy seeing where it's going though as AI can quite literally help push science into an entirely new world of possibilities since it can process far more data than humans can all within mere seconds. Scary for those with that job, but people will always be more trusted on it so they have nothing to fear. AI art doesn't compare to the real beauty of professional art, even when it copies it directly, it's warped and very different looking. So I guess really boils down to how fearful media has made you believe AI is. xD I don't care to watch news whining about AI being bad, because most of the time media posts like that are just meant to add shock factor to a rather insignificant issue. People fear too much in life it seems lol. But yeah, good game Detroit: Become Human and the Creator is a fantastic movie take on a very similar concept. As well, if you want the feels to hit, just watch that hidden video sneak peak for Detroit that was in Beyond Two Souls, hits hard and it's like...wow....I could see our country acting that way if an AI showed it had genuine feelings like that. The US in particular is made to fear others pretty heavily which is wrong and often so blown out of proportion it's near insanity.

AI is a tool like any other. Its use and purpose is entirely up to the discretion of its creator and user. It is not inherently a bad thing, but certainly can be. It is in the best interest of every human out there to always try to be better than the tools they use, as a tool should never be the master of you. If you overly rely on a tool to do things on your behalf, you will not find long term success. This applies to businesses and corporations as much as individuals. You must always be able to do the very things the AI can do, even if you do that particular task slowly. Computers and AI are there to speed tasks up and remove the tedium of work, not to be a creator or problem solver in your place.

AI defending China with the Iron Man milk deal: The scenario you're describing, where a localized version of a film like Iron Man includes a specific reference to a product like "Gu Li Duo" following a public health scandal, could indeed be interpreted in various ways depending on the context in which it was shown.  If it was officially part of the film, it might be seen as an attempt at humor, although it could certainly be in poor taste given the seriousness of the milk scandal. If it was not part of the official release and was instead added by a third party, it could be viewed as an insensitive joke or a form of commentary on the scandal.  In either case, the use of such a reference in connection with a beloved film character could be controversial. It could be seen as trivializing a serious issue, or it could be an attempt to satirize or bring attention to the event through popular media. Without additional context, it's difficult to determine the intent behind the inclusion of this message in the film screenings.  It's also worth noting that sometimes these kinds of messages are inserted into films without permission by local distributors or theaters, which could be considered a form of propaganda or simply a misguided attempt at local humor. The impact of such an addition would depend on how it's perceived by the local audience, which could vary widely.

Since we're on the topic of generative A.I, here's a brief primer on how A.I generated images works, since there's a *LOT* of misinformation online. Because, no, it's not simply making a collage using images from a library of stolen images.   How it actually works is the A.I is shown thousands and thousands of labelled images, and it uses these images to learn the shapes and colors of things. You show it a million images of dogs labelled as "dog" and it'll learn that a "dog" is typically something with four legs, a tail, floppy ears and covered in fur, for example. At this point, the training images are no longer needed, as it's already learned what it needs to know. This is why offline generators like Stable Diffusion are only around 6GB in size, instead of the terabytes and terabytes of images that would be required if it was simply making a collage.     When it comes to actually making an image, first, it's fed an image consisting of random noise. It then tries to "pull-out" the requested image by gradually re-arranging the noise to form the shapes of the things it's been requested to make an image of. Sorta like when you look at clouds and start seeing clouds that look like different things.   The fact that A.I image generation is inherently based on randomness, is why the results tend to be chaotic, and trying to get something specific is like trying to herd cats. This is the also the Achilles heel of A.I that makes it difficult for it to be the harbinger of doom that many artists fear. Whoever is opting to use A.I instead of hiring human artists, will have to come to terms with the fact that they will lack control over the output and will eventually have to accept whatever it is the A.I is giving you. Sure, that's not a problem in some situations. For example, the Palworld guys could very well have used A.I to generate the initial design concepts for their monsters, since "gimmie a bunch of images of monsters that look sorta like Pokemon" is the sorta thing it could do. But there's more to creating content than just this, and it's the ability of human artists to, y'know, follow instructions, that still means they're essential.

Seems like this is kind of a controversial take on the situation, but reallyâ€¦how is this any different from every other technological change that happens over the years.   New technology and tools come in that allow business, whether in Hollywood or elsewhere, to do things more effectively, save money, and sometimes drastically change how they operate.   And as with any change in the economy, it can be a detriment to some and a benefit to others, but eventually we will reach a new equilibrium.    Companies used to use typewriters all the time, and then computers came along, and the companies that made typewriters, and the people who could make a living repairing typewriters, probably went out of business or had to pivot to doing new things.    For the most part is not â€œmoralâ€ or â€œimmoralâ€ itâ€™s just changing times.   It makes sense that companies would want to use a technology that could save them money, and certainly the budgets for movies and tv have been ballooning to ridiculous levels as it is.   Seems like there are two responses; oppose the adoption of new technology or impose protections to make sure things donâ€™t change too much too quickly, or adapt to the changing reality and environment of the business.

If I need to try making art for the fantasy setting I'm building, I have neither the skills, time, nor money to get that done traditionally. Using an AI generator is, frankly, my only option at this time. A corporation with millions or billions of dollars, however, has no reason to use AI other than to enrich itself and lay off people who have dedicated their livelihoods to working on professional artwork.

If I am completely honest, as an illustrator who has been making art consciously for almost 10 years now, I would have no issue with AI if we didn't live under a system (capitalism) where supporting it will mean the loss of my only viable work option that doesn't make me feel depressed. If i didn't have to earn a living through making art, I would absolutely welcome it as a tool to help creators make a base from which they can work off of (and those who don't like it don't have to use it, because they wouldn't have to compete with ai-assisted art to keep their own jobs).  If we put aside some moral problems with the usage of AI for now, I think the problem isn't AI - the problem is the system under which its usage is directly linked to people's loss of ability to live somewhat comfortably doing what they love.

I'm a huge nerd for scifi stuff and the like, and think that it is so amazing that AI has come this far and continues to push the boundaries of our expectations. But as a writer, it's concerning. Small thing, but the â€œfrog in boiling waterâ€ thing is a myth. The scientist who popularized it was actually trying to find out what part of the brain consciousness was in. So, he lobotomized a bunch of frogs and then tested if they would still have self-preservation instincts. Turns out, a frog with no brain will indeed let itself be boiled, but an intact frog jumps out around 25Â° C

didnt mat leave youtube?
AI should be a tool to help creatives, not replace them. After all, without those creatives, AI has nothing to learn from. But people and companies are far too interested in the profit of the tool. Like, I get using AI for fun, nothing serious and harmless. But what really scares me is companies using AI to cut costs. Who needs artists and animators when you can use AI to make art for free? Who needs writers and authors when you can use AI to generate text for free? Who needs voice actors when you can use AI to replicate someone's voice? Who needs actors when you can use AI to deepfake someone in? And this is all just the creative side. Once there are no more jobs in the creative field to be replaced by AI, it'll be physical jobs next. Just because AI isn't affecting you now, it will in the future if people don't see it as an issue.  I know people who like AI really like it, but as a creative person myself, it's scary looking at the future. It's easy to think that there's no point to create stuff that takes hours of effort, when you can click some buttons to get close to the desired outcome. But even when I hate the progress of a drawing or I get frustrated by it, there's nothing quite like doing those finishing touches and being happy with the results.
While propaganda can promote any viewpoint or cause, I try to remember this quote by ALdous Huxley: "The propagandist's purpose is to make one set of people forget that certain other sets of people are human."  My benchmark, or grain of salt, for the danger of propaganda is figuring out how it might cause hurt or hate.

There's a simple solution - draft law or regulation where anything generated by AI can't be copyrighted. If the plot of the movie can't be copyrighted, the studio can't do anything about someone making a fully AI generated knockoff and dumping it free on the internet. The more of the visuals they let be whole-cloth generated by AI, the more of their film can be uploaded without recourse. That allows people to use it to its potential - something they will do anyway no matter what you do, while also giving a strong profit motive to pay actual humans to do what AI can do free so you can make money off it.  That said, 20 years from now you'll be able to buy consumer level AI software that will do what Hollywood does with it 10 years from now. If AI replaces your job, you are out of a job anyway. That is the march of technology. You aren't going to pay Disney for a non-AI movie if your neighbor down the street downloaded an open source AI that someone modded to generate just as good of content on demand for no cost to you. If you are one of the 0.0001% who REALLY care about this sort of thing, and aren't just thinking that you care now while it's in an abstract sense and you aren't actually paying the cost difference for non-AI, then you're probably going to live performances instead anyway.  We need to regulate what hardware AI is left in charge of because a biased AI in charge of a lethal drone is a recipe for atrocities, but generative AI is just a thing that will happen. Instead of protecting people's jobs, we need to dismantle the work-to-live social mindset and create a society where people can pursue meaningful existence that isn't defined by finding employment to feed their family.

I gather the studios who are endeavouring to improve our opinion of the application of AI in the creative spaces, don't really understand what the consequences of highly developed AI creators will be.  The ultimate consequence of having AI visual art, music, and video production is that individuals will be able to unlock their own imaginations and bring their stories to life.  Instead of having to make do with generic stories, with hit and miss characters, we will be able to write our own stories for our own personal use (as well as entertaining our friends if we so desire).  We will even be able to be prompted by AI to help us create better stories based on our own ideas.  It's the dawning of bespoke art.  Something a studio should find terrifying as they won't be able to compete with our own imaginations.  This technology is exactly the same kind of breakthrough that the original industrial revolution provided, in that, it allows ordinary people to take action according to their own imagination, unlocking ideas and skills no one in history had ever seen before.  This is that event on steroids and in an even smaller timescale.

It is actually amazing how disgusting and disingenuous the change of narrative about robots is in media. The cautionary tales of movies from before the turn of the century served a purpose of dismantling racism, specially in Japan. For countries with monolithic ethnic groups, using robots as a metaphor for the phenomenon of "othering" is a lot more effective than actually showing someone with another skin color as a teaching tool that can permeate slowly the minds of stubborn people. The real danger comes from where the data is coming from, if it is stolen or used without consent to cut on costs. The time where we have to impose data restrictions on AI should come, and that any gathering of data should be taxed based on the amount gathered. We should be respectful of this technology so that we can properly use it, and even more respectful our fellow people whose data is what is being used. I'm going to be honest I was too distracted by all of Disney's other propaganda to notice their pro AI propaganda.
Here's what I take away from this. Progress can be resisted, but is inevitable. We have crossed the threshold to where AI is simply a tool of the future. It will not be stopped; it's too inherently valuable and has developed too far to be ignored. The fact that Disney, and likely other entities, are pushing a pro-AI message is only further proof of this.  But with all tools AI is not inherently good or evil. Disney wants you to accept their version of the future and their use of AI, but you don't have to. Take time to consider what YOU want out of AI. What would make your life easier? What ethical considerations do you want in it's use? Push the ideas you want to see. Scream for the AI that helps not hurts. We may be in a market driven economy, but if enough of us call for practical and beneficial uses for AI we then get a seat at the table to decide what AI should NOT be used for.  Resistance to these kinds of changes only forfeits your say in how the future is formed. Instead embrace the change and make it work for you.

Detroit Become Human.
Introduction  Artificial Intelligence (AI) has become an integral part of our daily lives, offering numerous benefits that enhance efficiency, accuracy, and productivity. This essay is not intended as propaganda, but rather as an objective exploration of the positive impacts of AI.  Efficiency and Productivity  AI systems can process vast amounts of data at incredible speeds, making them highly efficient. They can perform tasks that would take humans significantly longer, freeing up human time for other activities. This increased efficiency leads to higher productivity in various sectors, from healthcare to manufacturing.  Accuracy and Precision  AI algorithms are designed to learn and improve over time, leading to high levels of accuracy and precision. In fields like medicine, this can lead to improved patient outcomes. For instance, AI can analyze medical images with a level of detail that surpasses human capability, potentially leading to earlier detection of diseases.  24/7 Availability  Unlike humans, AI systems can work around the clock without breaks or downtime. This constant availability is particularly beneficial in customer service, where AI chatbots can provide immediate assistance to customers at any time of the day or night.  Conclusion  While itâ€™s important to acknowledge and address the challenges associated with AI, such as privacy concerns and potential job displacement, the benefits of AI are substantial. By increasing efficiency and accuracy, and providing round-the-clock availability, AI has the potential to significantly improve our lives. This is not propaganda, but a recognition of the transformative power of technology when used responsibly and ethically.  Made by AI
