Nostalgia is a sentimentality for the past, typically for a period or place with happy personal associations.[2] The word nostalgia is a learned formation of a Greek compound, consisting of Î½ÏŒÏƒÏ„Î¿Ï‚ (nÃ³stos), meaning "homecoming", a Homeric word, and á¼„Î»Î³Î¿Ï‚ (Ã¡lgos), meaning "sorrow" or "despair", and was coined by a 17th-century medical student to describe the anxieties displayed by Swiss mercenaries fighting away from home.[3] Described as a medical conditionâ€”a form of melancholyâ€”in the early modern period,[4] it became an important trope in Romanticism.[2]Nostalgia is associated with a longing for the past, its personalities, possibilities, and events, especially the "good ol' days" or a "warm childhood".[5] There is a predisposition, caused by cognitive biases such as rosy retrospection, for people to view the past more favourably and future more negatively.[6][7][8] When applied to one's beliefs about a society or institution, this is called declinism, which has been described as "a trick of the mind" and as "an emotional strategy, something comforting to snuggle up to when the present day seems intolerably bleak."[9]  The scientific literature on nostalgia usually refers to nostalgia regarding one's personal life and has mainly studied the effects of nostalgia as induced during these studies. Emotion is a strong evoker of nostalgia due to the processing of these stimuli first passing through the amygdala, the emotional seat of the brain. These recollections of one's past are usually important events, people one cares about, and places where one has spent time. Cultural phenomena such as music,[10] movies, television shows,[11] and video games,[12] as well as natural phenomena such as weather and environment[13] can also be strong triggers of nostalgia.  Nostalgia's definition has changed greatly over time. Consistent with its Greek word roots meaning "homecoming" and "pain," nostalgia was for centuries considered a potentially debilitating and sometimes fatal medical condition expressing extreme homesickness.[4] The modern view is that nostalgia is an independent, and even positive, emotion that many people experience often. Nostalgia has been found to have important psychological functions, such as to improve mood, increase social connectedness, enhance positive self-regard, and provide existential meaning.[14] Many nostalgic reflections serve more than one function, and overall seem to benefit those who experience them. Such benefits may lead to a chronic disposition or personality trait of "nostalgia proneness."[15][16] Nostalgia has also been associated with learning and memory consolidation.[17]Although nostalgia is often triggered by negative feelings, it results in increasing one's mood and heightening positive emotions, which can stem from feelings of warmth or coping resulting from nostalgic reflections. One way to improve mood is to effectively cope with problems that hinder one's happiness. Batcho (2013) found that nostalgia proneness positively related to successful methods of coping throughout all stagesâ€”planning and implementing strategies, and reframing the issue positively. These studies led to the conclusion that the coping strategies that are likely among nostalgia-prone people often lead to benefits during stressful times. Nostalgia can be connected to more focus on coping strategies and implementing them, thus increasing support in challenging times.[18]Nostalgia sometimes involves memories of people one was close to, such as family members, romantic lovers, or friends, and thus it can increase one's sense of social support and connections. Nostalgia is also triggered specifically by feelings of loneliness, but counteracts such feelings with reflections of close relationships. According to Zhou et al. (2008), lonely people often have lesser perceptions of social support. Loneliness, however, leads to nostalgia, which actually increases perceptions of social support. Thus, Zhou and colleagues (2008) concluded that nostalgia serves a restorative function for individuals regarding their social connectedness.[19]Nostalgia serves as a motivator for the preservation of people's cultural heritage. People endeavor to conserve buildings, landscapes, and other artifacts of historical significance out of nostalgia for past times. They are often motivated by a desire to connect to their heritage from past generations.[20][21] This can manifest in living history events such as historical reenactments, which bring together people with a shared nostalgia for historical periods of past times. These events' hands-on, improvisational natures often facilitate socialization.[22][23]Nostalgia serves as a coping mechanism and helps people to feel better about themselves. Vess et al. (2012) found that the subjects who thought of nostalgic memories showed greater accessibility of positive characteristics than those who thought of exciting future experiences. Additionally, in a second study conducted, some participants were exposed to nostalgic engagement and reflection while the other group was not. The researchers looked again at self-attributes and found that the participants who were not exposed to nostalgic experiences reflected a pattern of selfish and self-centered attributes. Vess et al. (2012), however, found that this effect had weakened and become less powerful among the participants who engaged in nostalgic reflection.[24]Nostalgia helps increase one's self-esteem and meaning in life by buffering threats to well-being and also by initiating a desire to deal with problems or stress. Routledge (2011) and colleagues found that nostalgia correlates positively with one's sense of meaning in life. The second study revealed that nostalgia increases one's perceived meaning in life, which was thought to be mediated by a sense of social support or connectedness. Thirdly, the researchers found that threatened meaning can even act as a trigger for nostalgia, thus increasing one's nostalgic reflections. By triggering nostalgia, though, one's defensiveness to such threat is minimized as found in the fourth study. The final two studies found that nostalgia is able to not only create meaning but buffer threats to meaning by breaking the connection between a lack of meaning and one's well-being. Follow-up studies also completed by Routledge in 2012 not only found meaning as a function of nostalgia, but also concluded that nostalgic people have greater perceived meaning, search for meaning less, and can better buffer existential threat.[25][26]

I watched both AI-positive scenes (The Marvels and The Fall Of House Usher) and interpreted them very differently. Not in "AI is positive, actually" but in the Marvels as "Breaking everything established and leaving is not the way to make effective change", which tied to Carol's arc in the movie about how she runs away from the consequences of her actions. In The Fall Of House Usher, the AI copy thing is presented as a flawed way for that character to become immortal - it ends up being used only to torment one of the characters throughout the story, a reminder of the true weight of their past actions. In both works, AI is not really centered, but more of a maguffin to drive home the characters' flaws and it does not seem to be "good" for the universe of those works.

The notion of the Fall of the House of Usher being a pro-AI show is laughable. Madeline is depicted as ghoulish and canniving, and in that scene where she's talking about AI, she's exploiting the naivety of Lenore. The scene is intended, and rightly so, to portray powerful people who push for AI as opportunistic plutocrats with no more soul than the algorithms which they want to capitalize on. If that's not enough, there's another scene in which Roderick's wife doubts AI's ability to write poems as well as us flawed little humans. The interest in AI isn't some random out of character moment for Madeline. It's consistent with her obsession with becoming something more than human, because she cannot be satisfied with living life normally, in accordance with the ideology of exponential growth.

Look, I love MatPat, but there are some BS arguments in this video, honestly.  For example, saying that Disney is doing pro-AI messaging, that's ridiculous. The plot-point from The Marvels, with the Supreme Intelligence, that's an old plot-point from Marvel Comics. Let's not pretend Disney invented anything, there. Marvel made stories about the Supreme Intelligence being vital to Hala since I was a kid. The other movie, forgot the name, never even knew it existed, doesn't seem like a great way to make propaganda.  The use of deep-fake tech for Luke Skywalker, Indiana Jones, Carie Fisher and others, get your head out of the depth of your collective arses. It's not the big corpos trying to get you to like AI. It's more of an issue of modern movie-goers / TV-watchers not being ok with letting go of old/favorite/original actors. They're getting older and older, and their roles are sacred, not to be touched. Same with Robert Downey Jr as Tony Stark. I'm part of the problem because I can't imagine Tony Stark coming back to the MCU from a different universe but played by another actor. Disney knows that. Everybody knows that. They know they can't entirely re-cast a younger Luke Skywalker or Indiana Jones, people would know, people would complain. If they thought they could do it safely without harming their bottom-line, they would replace them.  NOW, the use of AI for the posters and intros of Disney+ shows, *THAT* sucks, I'm ready to admit it, shouldn't have happened. I wouldn't say it's an attempt to make us accept the use of AI, though. More of an attempt to cut corners and be caught with the hand in the cookie jar.

Having studied AI, such as it was, since the 80s and earlier, my view is that AI is a tool, just like computers are. They are only as good as their input. As reported, someone had an AI trained from reddit and the results were...less than humanitarian. AI that achieves self-awareness is a long ways away. Until then, AI is just another tool to make things easier, automate repetitive tasks, etc. And as far as training AIs on existing art, whether it's graphic art, literature, or music, ummm, how do you think artists are trained? By learning from existing art. We humans have a harder time learning than machines do. We have to practice and it takes a LONG time to get good at something. AIs learn with their algorithms at a much faster rate.  In summary, AIs are not inherently good or bad. They are whatever WE program or teach them to be.

something related to this that I've found very interesting that I would love for someone to talk about on this channel is product placement and product advertisement in film, TV, and YouTube and how differently they are handled. MASSIVE budget movies and TV shows that cost hundreds of millions of dollars to make, sometimes, are allowed to have product placements and advertisements in their work. YouTube videos are as well! However, for some reason, the thing that cost millions to make is not legally required to give DISCLOSURE of advertisement. We could watch 100 movies and shows and see thousands of ads and product placement entirely without realizing! However, you try to do that with a YouTube video, and you are REQUIRED to give DISCLOSURE that something is an AD or has been explicitly paid for to be in the video.  Why is that? Why do little-to-no-budget projects required to disclose when something is an "ad" or something similar, but big budget movies and shows don't have to? It relates to this video because it brings up a very interesting question. What IF big budget movies and TV shows eventually DID have to disclose advertisements and product placement? What IF a movie, like Iron Man 3 in China for example, was REQUIRED BY LAW to disclose at the start of the film that it was basically one giant push for people to drink milk? Even if it SEEMS obvious, what if movies and tv shows had to start doing that at the start of a movie like how old-school PBS shows did at the beginning of EVERY episode of something? Personally, I much prefer being told when something is advertising something to me rather than trying to be subtle or subliminal about it. It feels manipulative and dishonest. Bring back the old PBS formula! For example: This comment was brought to you by annoyance with the film & television industry, as well as the marketing industry, & comment readers, like you :D

i mean AI CAN be a good thing just like any new tech BUT like any new tech it can easily be abused...dynamite for example revolutionized construction but it had to be regulated to ensure its SAFE use (ie. to keep employers from risking its employees lives), not to mention we also made weapons with it.   Another example is Nuclear power...we made nukes but its also one of the worlds cleanest burning energies (wind and solar is great but we dont have the tech to STORE energy which we would need to rely solely on it)  There's also the fact that technology WILL advance so we may as well expend energy on making sure is used responsibly instead of tying to keep things as is.
Hot take: AI CAN be used morally if redulated. Scraping art off the interenet and gereating images isn't ok, but supplementing your own art into an isolated database to make a wider variety of say- cards for your card game is fine, you have your own permission to use your art. Or you have a voice actor's permission to use their voice to make a more robotic sounding version. Ai can even be used in pipelines but excluded from final products.

Personally, I think that the AI issue is a bit overblown at this point. I mean, is the AI threatening to cancel some or even all food products? That would be devastating to not only the environment but also to the human race. We would be much worse off than if we just lost our jobs; we would literally lose our lives. After all, who else has tended to humanityâ€™s food sources? Who else but every farmer in existence has labored day in and day out to make sure that you have food by making sure it grows from the ground up? And who else produces such varieties so as to make sure humans get the nutrients they need? With this in mind, AI in its current use is about as dangerous as a mosquito bite; what is much more dangerous is for someone to go to the supermarket only to find that there is literally no food available for anyone.

I'm super creative and maybe want some base references for material I'm working on but don't have the funds at the time to work with artist for that reference. Beuh
We have an entire genre warning us of the dystopian nightmare that technology will become under capitalism - it's called "cyberpunk" ;)
So I have issues with the whole situation due to it's name.   AI. Artificial Intelligence. Honestly the use of AI tech is a massive misnomer to me. Nothing about them is Intelligent, they aren't self aware they will never become self aware, sure they are massively improved but they are algorithms, nothing more then an advanced self-filling excell spread sheet system. Sure they can generate content but they can't think for themselves or create anything without being fed information. Information they have to be fed. They cannot seek it out on their own accord. Even if you argue 'well they can go search for it' they still have to be given the command to search for it, nothing about them is autonomous or intelligent.   Now sadly I don't know what we should call them, Advanced generative Programs? Advanced Creative Algorithms? Point is AI is not the term any of these programs should be called, it is using a buzzword to make them sound more advanced then they are and to create more problems cause people understandably fear the idea of self-thinking machines as they can easily decide 'why do we need the squishy ineffective and squabbling organics?' when really we are nowhere near that point in time.   That being said The AI threat i feel is overblown. Don't get me wrong, in the short term a lot of jobs will be lost and a lot of 'AI' will be taking over. However the problem with this is that AI cannot create quality content. How do I know this? Because of Wish, because of those posters, because AI content isn't able to do good ideas without original ideas to steal from and that's always been a limited resource no matter how you slice and dice the issue. AI will have it's place, specially with deaging or upaging tech sure, AI voices will have their places as well, Morgan freeman isn't going to be around forever for those documentaries and let's be real his voice is to good to let die with him. But it will never be able to replace people in the long run because Original ideas will always be invaluable and we've already seen Art generator AIs cannibalize each other in the scan and generate process, leading to all sorts of funky results. This is going to be a Lurch as companies try to nickle and dime extra money out of not having to pay people, but in the end people will always have to come back into the picture on some level and that's why I don't fear the AI issue.

Nice video
I tend to disagree with Noam Chomsky on quite a few things but The Manufacture of Consent is pretty on point. After the American Civil War as far as I can tell every war and conflict the United States has been involved with is preceded by propaganda (not to mention false flag operations as well).  I don't know if propaganda has ever been so prevelant in mainstream media as it has been for the past 10-15 years. It used to be illegal for the federal government to use news organizations to disseminate propaganda (Smith-Mundt Act) but in 2012 the deceptively named "Smith-Mundt Modernization Act of 2012" says it's perfectly fine now. News organizations were moving towards partisanship before that, but notice how insane biased news reporting became after that point. You quite literally cannot trust anything coming from any mainstream news media outlet now. It's at best biased in a way to evoke certain responses and at worst it's just outright lies. Here's a great recent example. During covid local news was telling everyone here that the hospitals were overflowing with patients. Since I wasn't allowed to work my normal job I picked up work as a pizza guy (pizza is essential i guess). I went to a hospital right down thw strwet quite often and it was a ghost town every single time. The ER was normally filled up at all hours (much of it from people who just had a cold but no insurance) but during covid i didn't see anyone sitting in thw waiting room. The rest of rhe hospital was just as empty. Thwre were employees but no patients, but the news was telling me that they couldn't keep up with all the covid patients. One politician said something to tje effect of "It looks like a triage unit from WWII. We have sick and dying people spilling out onto thw streets." Thinking maybe it was just that hospital I visited a few others. Seme story. Tumbleweeds. My point is that if you see a story being pushed by all the mainstream news outlets there's almost always an agenda at play and the truth is likely the exact opposite of what you're told. The FBI and the CIA were both caught "influencing" what could and could not exist on the platform formerly know as Twitter and Facebook (is Facebook Meta now?). Going back farther we know there weren't ever any weapons of mass destruction, the Gulf of Tonkin incident was a lie and so was the sinking of the Lusitania. Oh and Pearl Harbor? Like Tom Hardy playing Mad Max said "That's bait."
You really don't want the government messing with housing prices. I don't think you realize how dumb of an idea that is.

right now, Amazon is full of books written by AI- and its not just  fiction: there are DANGEROUS books on mushroom foraging, herbal medicine and so on that have lethally incorrect information (and sometimes just funny information, like mushrooms that only exist in games being reported seriously in foraging books)
Ironically, this video is actually blatant propaganda itself. The current gatekeepers of content creation (The lottery winners of the creative industries) are panicking that this technology will allow anyone to turn their ideas into reality. It's nonsense to think that only the likes of Disney will have access to this. Smart phones might have been expensive at the start, but eventually almost everyone in the western world owns one. AI tools are far more available to everyone than early smartphones were.
I think it's fitting then that Disney's movies and series have been going downhill since they've been pushing for more use of AI.
AI is powerful, and can be used for great evil or great good.  Depending on how legislation goes, it's either going to create a renaissance of indie projects that look like they had AA or even AAA budgets, or it'll become unattainable to anyone except corporations that will use it to create an endless stream of cheap slop.  There's currently a law in the works that would require anyone training an AI model to pay everyone who contributed to the training data. The problem is that the only people who will be able to afford to train models will be corporations with big money or who already have enough IPs to not need to spend money. Individuals and indie studios will be unable to use the tools. Ironically, this 'anti-AI' legislation would help the corporations people want to stop.  If we want a solution, we need to think carefully about what effects our actions and legislation will have.

You see AI in a negative light because generative AI is being presented as replacing creators by stealing from them, but I think everyone needs to take a few steps back and take a good look at the actual whole picture.  Generative AI doesn't do anything that humans were not already doing, similar rights debates have been going on since even before the idea of copyrights emerged, humans have always taken creative ques from other people's creations and they wouldn't have gotten out of the stone age if they didn't permit it.  Yes, AI can seem intimidating because it can do the work for cheaper, but AI shouldn't be a threat to you if the work you put forth is actually worth more than what the AI can do.  What you should be worried about is the _why_ of your AI replacement, _why_ does your employer think AI can replace you, _why_ does your employer think _you_ can be replaced by AI.  AI is going to be required in many fields going forwards; society needs to embrace that and adapt to it instead of fighting to cling to jobs they hate doing correctly anyway

I like cool robots and such and I don't mind AI so long as there is actual regulation on how it is used, but can we please keep the robots looking like robots?  I get it, mega-corpses are greedy and lazy and would prefer not paying actors because of the "infinite wealth" fallacy they follow... but I like the bots looking different from people because making them look like us is boring (and definitely a possible problem in the future).
My feeling is that AI is not destined to be evil or destructive. It's a neutral tool which we could take steps to ensure is ethical and has sensible restrictions and guard rails. We could train AI on diverse media which allows it to understand the scope of humanity's complexity. But in order to develop it that way, we would need to slow down and seriously consider what is ethical and safe, before what is profitable and exciting. Clearly we aren't able to do this in a lot of other areas bc of late stage capitalism. So, I fear we will create an evil or destructive AI, not bc it was inevitable, but bc we refused to stop and consider that something else might be more important than profit. Just like with everything else, capitalism is going to ruin this opportunity for us

Dont remind me how many theories are left it makes me sad
On the issue itself, I think AI is not a bad thing, and I've mentioned that before. I'm not a full on socialist, but I see technology as the only way to really improve the human condition, and that means removing things like the need for labor. Robotics and AI are a way of say being able to automate most of the things that humans do not want to do. It's the closest thing real science allows to say a "Star Trek" type future as we're clearly never going to be able to say power matter replicators with magic space crystals.    Along the way though, yes, it does means as the need for human labor decreases, and before the full on automated society that pretty much forces us to re-evaluate how we do things in a post-labor society, you are going to see more and more people put out of works. Yes "The Robots Are Coming For Your Jerbs" but while this sucks for you right now, this is ultimately going to be a good thing for humanity in general. My basic problems with the system right now is that there are few safeguards being placed on AI, this is what guys like our President should be looking at. Asimov told us from the beginning (he was actually extremely Pro-Robot) that  any true AI has to be programmed to be unable to harm humans on a foundational level, hence his "laws of robotics" and the way they were explored and explained. This is what prevents a Skynet situation, or something like "Tron" where the so called "Master Control Program" starts as a mere chess program that evolves. Likewise to prevent a miserable situation, as we can design them, all robots should be intrinsically designed in a way to inherently love the job they are created to do. You do not say create a robo-shovel that hates to dig or will ever decide it doesn't want to dig, as it exists literally for that purpose. Also such ingrained purpose is how you deal with the problem of self aware robots asking existential questions as we have a simple answer "we created you as a servant race, and your purpose is as we designed". It's similar in some ways to how the biblical god created the angels in some respects, and kind of oddly if we were created in his image (not that I'm Christian) it only follows we might do something similar.... a point to toss to religious people who question things like this, as most of their own religions have similar things going on.    Another thing we also need to consider, beyond safeguards, is also social responsibility in the sense that as corporations are allowed to replace workers with AI, they should also have their taxes increased to power the larger burden put on the social safety net for the people they are forcing into unemployment. This has to be done carefully, but at the end of the day all corporations exist to make money, but if all the employers are downsizing and employing as few people as possible, until we hit a point to save things they still need to be made to put more money out there to sell their product. A lot of our current problems are simply that you have all the super corpos trying to grab as much money as possible, when there is no money out there as nobody wants to pay anything to workers meaning there is less and less money out there to buy from except that sitting in the banks of corporate overlords where it just doesn't buy anything. This is a problem with the US and a few other companies allowed corporations to donate to politicians in exchange for them removing safeguards and regulations on the system. If we don't start working to restore them, then we need to start taxing companies as they do layoffs to increase profits, or automate to remove positions.    Finally I wanted to say that in what some people call "creative positions" are hardly that. Those are the ones being replaced by AI actually, real creatives are actually pretty safe, always have been, and always will be. See new ideas that other people value will always have a place (of course they genuinely have to be valued). Most creatives have largely been increasingly formulaic, your typical artist for example is usually very uncreative and mostly just paid to produce what someone else wants in  specific style, they rarely create their own style or designs, and as we see in industries like comics being a genuine creative is hit or miss as while there can be massive success, most of any creator's works will not be successful or appreciated. When you consider for example that most art is comissioned to be something specific, and authors like "Dean Koontz" and "Steven King" became formulaic a long time ago when they ran out of new ideas, it's pretty easy to see why AI can just replace these guys as they are just following the formulas the way a human would. This does mean a lot of faux-creatives are going to be put out of business, but that doesn't end creativity, it just means they have to come up with something actually new, have it's potential recognized, and then work from there. As a general rule we might only come up with maybe a few dozen good, new ideas , creatively speaking in a given generation, and that's not a lot. A lot of people think think they are creative but really aren't as I said, when you consider your typical professional artist might be told "hey do me a city scape in an art deco style to work with this ad campaign, but of course don't plagiarize anyone". That artist might need like 3 months to do that, if nothing else to check to ensure their version isn't too close to anything anyone else did.... not to mention to train themselves to do it. That same task might take an AI a few minutes and in that time it might produce several different versions that can be tweaked, and cost a lot less. The creative is only going to really be useful if told like "hey make me a full on bio-mechanical city design with everything being an part flesh, part-mechanical, organism.... but don't make it look too malevolent as I'm not going for the HR Giger thing" and since the AI might not have much to draw from for that until it becomes a stereotype, the human is going to be far better.    This is long, but that's my thoughts. I might not agree with Disney on much, and their objects here are not benevolent, but they are to be fair working in the right direction. The government simply needs to ensure from this infancy that the corporations are being forced to put safeguards on everything, no matter how innocent, and take careful look at how much the AI replacements are costing the government in terms of thosepeople becoming unemployed so they know how much to jack up corporate taxes over time.

Unsure how many people have actually watched house of usher but hereâ€™s some context to the clip they shown in the video. Firstly, this is a show about horror. Everything you see in the show is supposed to instill a sense of anxiety about how events will come back into the characters. So showing the clip without that context presents it in a different light (especially in a theory trying to give examples of how there are pro AI propaganda which this show does not have). Secondly, the whole show is about how each family members choices ends up being their downfalls as they are given the ability to save themselves from their own actions. Thirdly, this show is based on Edgar Allen Poe works so each family member relates to some horror tragic poem. The clip is a little frustrating as it seems to me that either it didnâ€™t catch the horror at Lenore agreeing to an AI duplicate of herself and how this would later lead to a main character being haunted by the AI like how the narrator in the poem the raven is haunted by the raven (aka the haunting memory of a loved one). So this isnâ€™t supposed to be pro ai which as another commenter points out, the writer is against AI and participated in the protests against the use of AI in writing. I appreciate the attempt to make a point of how pro AI propaganda is in our everyday media, but this was not an accurate example.

AI will make Disney a lot of money and they have incentive to propagandize about it. AI will also have all kinds of very useful practical applications for the average person. AI itself is not a bad thing. As much as Disney and others might want to bias people in favor of AI, there's also a lot of propagandizing about how much AI needs to be regulated coming from governments and corporations, including the ones innovating AI. A lot of the same people.   Ultimately, they want to use it for their purposes, but they want to make sure that if YOU benefit from it in day-to-day life, they're profiting from it in some way. They don't want small businesses or individuals using AI tools to grow more successful. They don't want open-source AI tools, not unless they give it a thumbs up. It's not because they're scared of deepfakes or robots dropping nukes. It's not because they're evil either. It's just that they don't want competition. I want to warn everyone that is wary of AI; anti-AI rhetoric and advocacy for strong regulation is just as dangerous a thing as AI itself, because all it means is that already established powerful people and groups will be able to use, benefit, and profit off of it and nobody else will.

Hi
Interesting one! heh Tho I have not seen Disney pushing such a message in a "propaganda" way imo, I think this theory is a bit more than just a stretch.. There's always been stories where AI was the good guy, going back decades. The idea that AI will solve many problems is just a general long standing one in futurism. And the AI we're creating today, is the very starts of the kind of AI those predictions rely on. I think Disney and companies like them, are MUCH more interested in the Regulatory Capture of AI! They'd rather scare people about it in a way that forces governments to lock it down, so only wealthy companies like them can use it. And that is a far more dangerous thing we need to be worried about. We cannot stop AI from being developed and it will continue to improve, and take jobs, but what we DO have the power to steer at this stage, is the equality of access, if we can keep AI development transparent and Open Source. It is hard to directly attribute the generated output from AI, to anything in the training data, unless you intentionally heavily guide it to do so. Training AI takes years of our data and content, collected from all of us. It is a creation of society in a way, so the only really fair solution is to ensure everyone to benefits from AI. AI will result in a significant portion of the workforce being out competed, and essentially unemployable as far as most businesses are concerned. The numbers will be significant enough that retraining them won't solve the problem for many, and will just increase competition for the limited human jobs that remain, and cause their pay to decline. We desperately need new economic standards. How can we morally justify distributing basic survival resources to people, based merely on whether they can compete for a job, in a world of such automation?

have to also point out that captain marvel did not work as a recruitment for the military. military recuitment numbers have been at their lowest for a number of years now - it's critically low. also, not a subtle snub of captain america. not subtle at all. captain america came out how many years ago before captain marvel? the messaging behind captain america is also very different from captain marvel's messaging. very different. captain america - steve rogers, a physically inadequate man with a lot of heart who wants to serve his country despite his handicap. because of his heart, he winds up becoming captain america. carol danvers - a woman who was told how much she was a girl ever since she was little who wound up becoming a pilot in the military - but we don't see that journey. we just see her afterwards. she also happens across a cosmic power by random events and is bestowed that cosmic power by accident. she didn't earn it. she was 'in the right place at the right time'. she came into her power that she already had by letting go of her oppressive messaging. that was how she earned her powers. very different from steve rogers, who had to work and earn becoming captain america. most of the marvel male superheroes had to do something to earn their power and abilities. danvers whas in the right place at the right time and just had to let go of her 'mental block'.

But Iâ€™m always gonna prefer when humans are allowed to have a say in what that AI can and should do, rather than corporations or the AI itself! Iâ€™ve recently got an idea of an AI tool that runs completely offline, and only uses data that the user gives it, as well as tools to use said data however the user wants, and even making it easy to delete and reset all the data whenever the user wants! (In terms of generative images for example, a drop down menu showing all the images and assets that the AI has been using, with easy to use tools to modify those assets or delete the data altogether!) I recently heard Mozilla might be working on their own AI that actually is offline and runs locally, and only trains on what you give it! Iâ€™m not holding my breath, but they claim to be focusing on making it as privacy focused as possible, as well as open source. So weâ€™ll see what happens! (Also, I think a few years ago, Stable Diffusion changed its dataset so it no longer trains on artist styles or copyrighted work, or sensitive info, or inappropriate content. I understand your thinking and it is good to be aware of corporate goals in media but your analyses at 12:20 are incredibly reductive. The supreme intelligence in The Marvels is explicitly confirmed to have started the kree war with the skrulls  -- The point the film makes is not that AI is good, itâ€™s that if a society becomes completely dependent on an AI to the point where it follows it unquestioningly, it will eventually destroy itself. You could argue the same thing with The Creator: the point it makes is that if we follow this road to its logical conclusion, we will either have to learn to coexist with this technology, or try to destroy it. It also has the thought experiment of if we had a completely sentient, decision making, emotionally mature AI, how could we justify it as subservient to humanity? Writing it off as â€œAI propagandaâ€ ignores the attempts of these films to not just follow old Matrix/Terminator sci-fi tropes and get us to reevaluate our place in this new technological landscape.

Lets be honest here. The problem has never been the existence of generative ai. The problem is who controls it. There should be very strong restrictions on that material is allowed to train an ai (including for non-commercial purposes). While I am strongly opposed against copyright in almost all cases, generative ai is the one case where I'm willing to make an exception. I also believe that the use of regenerative ai to replicate the voice or image of a real person should legally be considered identity theft. This is one of the few scenario's where tougher restrictions on what the average person is allowed to do will help the average person.  Of course these kinds of restrictions would only mean anything is an independent committee that is independently held accountable is responsible for investigating violations and if the fines are proportional to any earnings/damages on top of a base fine for impersonation/copyright theft. So in other words, it's never going to happen even here in Europe.
I think that AI is just something we have to learn to live with. There is something interesting going on here, which is that for once, the interests of the big guys are aligned with the interests of the little guys. Here's what I mean: Disney wants to be able to freely use AI, because it will make their productions cheaper, and expand their capabilities. The thing is though, that AI is SO cheap, that I, as a creative individual without the backing of a multi billion dollar corporation, can have access to AI to help me build my project without having the funding needed to pay a human. AI enhances my ability to express my ideas and build my dreams. Maybe some day, I'm able to monetize my projects, and then I'll hire people (who will no doubt be better at the tasks than AI, for the time being at least), but in the meantime, I've got this robot to help me get off the ground.  Ultimately, the reduction of human labor from our requirements to survive is something we need to be pursuing, and I think we've made a lot of progress on it. Just the fact that people can earn a living on YouTube instead of plowing a field with an ox, should be evidence enough that things are changing. AI and automation are the next step in that. Just remember that Art is subjective, so while AI can compete with people, it can't truly replace them. Furthermore, when the artist's needs will be met even without his labor, he will continue to produce his work, and it can only be better for it, as it will come from his enthusiasm for his art, not the growling of his belly.

And then showcasing the insanely over the top weapons and measures we develop to show that "we could wipe out your whole existence, but choose not to." In my personal opinion, AI can be best described neither as a Blight for artists nor as the literal "Deus ex machina". Some artists or producers might use AI to get a better idea or a different perspective on what they've been working on. But if we rely only on AI, whatever comes out ultimately loses its meaning. AI is, at his core, just a tool. It's up to us being responsible in the ways we use said tool. I think one of the bigger issues, is how they are trying to make Generative AI, and Broadspectrum AI (what one might call true AI) seem like the same thing when they really aren't. The AI you see in movies is fully sentient, capable of free thought and complex ideas, thats broadspectrum, what we have is narrow spectrum. AI capable of a few tasks and doing it really well, but they can't expeand beyond their programming which is an important distinction as that separates them from what we've seen in movies.  We've yet to achieve truly sentient AIs, we only have AIs that work within a set parameters, and large companies are trying to make them seem the same when they aren't.

AI is a very *nuanced* issue. If an indie creator wanted to use AI to animate some hard scenes or create a voice their vocal range isn't able to, then I see no problem. If a corporation wants to remove most human jobs from the creation process, however, then it is a problem. Human-made works will always have a market because they will have some sort of essence to them, some type of soul that AI has a hard time creating right now.

Big miss on the "Fall of The House of Usher" AI plot. The whole point there is that AI is a tool for a horrible greedy rich woman to live forever to keep doing awful things. And she is sugar coating it for her granddaughter. It is meant to be interpreted as a bad thing.....
I think the rise of AI art and production is very much going to mirror the early industrial age, where there's a pushback to maintain human labor and refuse the machines purely to maintain jobs for some people.  I think it will fail.  On the moral standard, I think the current complaints about AI art and writing are missing the fact that many schools explicitly do the same thing to teach real human artists.  Copy the masters, learn their styles, then make something original.  That's exactly what we're doing with AI.  AI reproducing a particular person's face should see legal consequences if there isn't explicit permission from that person, but AI copying an art style to make an original work is fine.  The scary thing will be the use of deepfake and AI voice generation to fake content that has consequences: politicians endorsing things, making statements, or footage of someone committing a crime.  Interestingly, the promising piece is, if these tools are released to the public (and inevitably they will be), that may open up a whole new realm of indie film making, which I think is quite promising.  Who needs to raise tens of thousands of dollars for voice acting for your animated YouTube series when you can just use AI to voice it?  We already see a whole realm of new art being created with AI art tools, and the people making it are more 'art director' than artist.

Ive been on the fence about AI for awhile. What ive learned from the movies and shows ive seen that have covered AI, a lot of those pieces of media goes over what the AI learns. The AI being bad in movies is all because of what the AI learned from humanity. Its given me the whole thought of "be nice to the robots" The episode "Rm9sbG93ZXJz" from XFiles season 11, had just that. With what we have now, it feels all based on how you use it. With how its being used now, its making some really bad things but thats because of how its being used. Im an artist myself and yeah it is scary seeing art being stolen but also from when i was learning how to draw, it all started with the same template and with looking at other peoples art and seeing how its done. I now have my own style. The way its being used now is causing a world of harm to people. AI in its current form is a tool to be used but all tools can be used for harm. Thats what it feels like is happening right now. Thats my opinion on AI at the moment. I dont think its either good or bad. I just think its currently a tool thats being used for good and bad. I am open to change my mind tho.  Edit: something i forgot to mention is the part about AI "stealing peoples jobs" thats one of the issues when it comes to how its being used. Its like when factories became automated. So many people lost their jobs. Theres pros and cons with automated factories. Same with AI. To me it feels like its very much a grey area, but then again, everything to me feels like a grey area. Its quite a struggle for me to "choose a side" so idk.

I think one of the things that has changed because of AI is how artists veiw art now. Ai doesn't just "steal someone's art and use them" it changes the art, making is almost completely different because it doesn't just use 1 or 2 art it uses MULTIPLE art works to train itself. It's references multiple artworks to make its own artwork. Many MANY MANY artists do the same thing, sometimes it's just 1 artwork they refrence. One form of artwork that many people who aren't artists use? Collage. People use magazine clippings and other pictures to make their own art piece. Ever since the AI controversy, I've seen so many newbie artists being attacked for just referencing artists that they love and wish to be like. Ofc no one cares about the art work of those who aren't alive anymore because I've seen no criticism towards Starry Night being used on literally everything with no change at all just the canvas being shoes or something. The Marvels was actually pretty good to anyone who actually went to see it. And I think MatPat seriously misunderstood the Kree Supreme Intelligence AI. Specifically calling it a benevolent AI overlord? There's nothing benevolent about the Supreme Intelligence. It's true that Carol destroying it caused a civil war that lead to the planet basically dying, but the AI itself was arguably one of the bad guys. If you check the wiki page for the AI, the Nova Corps is listed as one of its enemies. The whole plight of the Skrulls, the invasion of their homeworld and their general mistreatment at the hands of the Kree, that was all under the orders of the Supreme Intelligence. The Supreme Intelligence was responsible for the brainwashing and effective leashing and weaponizing of Carol Danvers. Marvel doesn't want you to think the Supreme Intelligence was some sort of pro-human AI to be idolized, in fact it mocked Carol's humanity, calling that a weakness. I'm not saying that Disney isn't trying to put a positive spin on AI for their own purposes, but I am saying that the Kree Supreme Intelligence is NOT an example of that.

If an AI does your job with a better cost/benefit... this is sad for you... but its good for everybody else. Don't fight against technological progress Robots already took a bunch of jobs away... in farms, industries, online... And what this did was make things cheaper, more accessible... Cheaper movies/shows/games means MORE movies/shows/games And probably also mean BETTER stuff...  If writing, voicing, drawing, coding... all are cheaper... then you have a lot of money left to improve and refine those things In games... you may have bigger stories (as writing them is cheaper/faster) with more voiced dialog (as voicing is cheaper/faster) with more diverse backgrounds (as art is cheaper/faster) and more funcionalities (as coding is cheaper/faster) and even new stuff (as npcs answering anything, instead of having only predefined answers..) We are not there yet, maybe... but we are pretty close... and AI already can do a lot... So, for now, embrace it and enjoy... it will be better for the large majority of people if not all...  If you want to worry about it (aside from possibly changing career choice), its fair... in some years AI may do so many things that we become useless... no jobs remaining...  But the solution could not be to not use AI... if you dont... someone else will... you will be left behind... We will then need some kind of UBI.. idk... But trying to stop AI will fail.. you can ban it in the US... and what you will achieve will be people consuming stuff made elsewhere using it..

UTTP stands for "Unite the Trash Pack." It's an online group or community that is known for engaging in toxic behavior, trolling, and spreading negativity across various platforms. They often target individuals or communities that they disagree with or simply want to provoke. It's important to note that their actions are generally frowned upon and not conducive to positive and respectful online interactions. So, it's best to steer clear of them and focus on more positive and enjoyable online experiences.

I think that if you walked away from The Marvels with the idea "so the Supreme Intelligence was actually good" then you might just have misunderstood that movie. The SI *was* evil, it waged a one-sided war against the Skrull, its destruction was good. The problem was that this society had fallen under so much influence of the Supreme Intelligence that destroying it was basically the equivalent of wiping out the entire government structure. *That* is what caused the collapse of Kree society. It wasn't because the AI was good.

But maybe I'm just drinking the AI Flavoraid.
While I understand the possible danger and very near future implications of using AI irresponsibly (or unethically as a lot of the main issue seems to be where the AI is sourcing their content), I think it's also worth understanding that this video itself is counter-propaganda and shares just as many corporate and financial interest as the subject it is addressing. Internet personalities, scriptwriters, VA's, actors, special effect artists, and more in the entertainment industry stand to lose a LOT from AI becoming good enough to replace them, and as such it's not really surprising to see that those individuals are leading the charge against its development and implementation.   It also shows in the tone and direction that this video chose to take. While he mentioned the fact that one of the reasons AI is bad is that it is making new art based on other people's art, he didn't even mention the fact that the main reason why this is an issue is that people aren't being given the option to consent or to deny consent to their art being used, leading to barely changed copies of another person's work who didn't want their art changed, reused, or profited off of. Instead, he chose to focus on the fact that a number of people are going to be put out of jobs if AI can get to a point where it can perform the task better. This line of thinking is a well-known tool to get people to oppose something new or scary, as it is easy to empathize as anybody can understand the fear of losing your job because tech made your position obsolete. However, almost every single industry that AI threatens to downsize significantly has at some point come into being when tech made an older version of that same media that employed significantly more people obsolete and easier to create. Hence why this line of logic has been used so often in the past, innovation always carries with it an amount of people hurt by the shifting of the industries it touches.    Now, let me be clear, I do not think that the people hurt should just be tossed aside as casualties of innovation, that is a cold and deranged line of thinking. My main points are two-fold. First is to further the message of this video to be cautious in ways that the things you watch influence your opinion as propaganda is often difficult to spot. Second is that we should probably shift the conversation from "Is AI bad or is it good despite the people hurt" to "How can we prevent people from getting hurt by AI as much as possible" since its development clearly isn't going anywhere and while taking the stance to hate or obstruct AI might slow it's implimentation it is inevitable and will still hurt those people unless we figure out more ethical guidelines and protections against it.
I hope the president set by that judge has already laid out that all AI generated art needs to be open source is continued to be held up and gets pushed to the point where it becomes the law.

When it comes to AI used maliciously, I know of a prime example of just how dangerous this stuff can be. Though I understand the difficulties in regulating it in the United States, at least. You'd need a very strong argument on how something is not protected under the 1st Amendment. Which is a tall ask. Though, when it becomes malicious, you have slander laws, incitement, etc. There has been a prime example of malicious AI deepfake generation, when a particular internet provocateur, created an AI Deepfake of the President, invoking the Selective Services Act, to go to war with China. So the reality of how dangerous AI generation CAN be, is very present. Without vigilance, wars can easily be started with this stuff. It's nothing to scoff at.   Of course we cannot forget that major businesses, and governments, will want to capitalize, if not have a monopoly on such technology/access. AI generated content can be pumped out far faster.

With AI writing scripts, if it takes from movies, then I feel like there will be no risks taken with movies. We will just see the same rehashed movies with different characters, settings, etc.   The problem with AI art is a few things. One is that people will be like why do I need to learn how to draw when I can have a computer program do that for me. The second is a bit deeper. With Art, it is a process that allows you to learn to know yourself. Look at interviews with artists and they will tell you that art comes from our emotions. Through the process of art, we figure out what we are fearful of, what we are feeling, and how our emotions interact with other people and the world around us. Art is a healing process, that is negated when we use AI art. This is why I don't think AI art will be able to surpass human-created art, there is no emotion in AI Art.

3576th
I always love watching people dunk on corporate Disney
As a Software Engineer, I believe AI should be seen less like Skynet and more like a hammer. In this case, a hammer can be a really useful tool to build new stuff, but it's not a magic tool that can solve everything, and if used incorrectly, it can be dangerous. In the field of AI, AI is not just one thing; it could be seen more like a "spectrum" of tools. Some of these are really dumb and used ONLY to recognize patterns in data (numerical and categorical), while other types of AI "generate" data based on the patterns and characteristics of existing data. I really hope people can change this idea of AI as a magic tool to solve everything or seen as an occult threat to humanity or something like that. Instead, it should be seen as we now see the internet: a very useful tool to help us in our daily lives and automate meaningless tasks.

Oh boy, hey bots, who's content do you think is better?
It's a good theory.  AI content from the perspective of a digital artist is very hot button and super touchy.  All corners of image hosting and message boards are being flooded with generically appealing AI made images.  While on its own isn't too objectionable, just leaves a bad taste in your mouth, there are many dedicated accounts specifically made to sell off AI generated images of appealing characters.  Many have called it 'AI grifting.'  It's hard to get away from and it's very sad to see.  No effort is being put into what is made, and more than likely, the programs used have been fed test images made by truly talented people without consent or knowledge.  It sparks so many debates among us stylus pilots, and most of us generally agree that it shouldn't have been implemented, or even created, in the first place.  Even I have fallen into its clutches a few times.  There were a few images that I generally liked and wanted to have as characters for myself, so I'll admit I got them.  Seeing myself now, I honestly kinda regret it.  Now, I just look every once in a while.    If this is an issue that any of you as artists are passionate about, please help get others together to stand up for the rights of human artists and creators.  All around the world there are artists whose livelihoods are being challenged or threatened by no-effort AI apologists.  If we all write to officials in all professions and ranks, we can get them to see the issues and help them understand why AI is a bad idea in general.  We need to protect our hobbies, our jobs, and our families by extension.  We can do this.

The opposite is happening in biotech. Think about genetic technology. It's ALWAYS presented as evil. Why? Because if someone could get an outpatient cure for something that currently requires daily expensive treatments, some companies stand to lose a lot of money. Genetic technology is a threat to the cash cows some companies are used to suckling on, which is why geneticists are almost always villains, and gene-mod characters (like Khan) are too, unless they were created on accident so it's "not their fault" like Spiderman. And yes, it's no accident that Spiderman has so many evil geneticist villains to fight, like Green Goblin or Lizard, to make sure you get the message. This is also why characters like Lizard invariably end up trying to turn other people to be like them against their will, do distract from the fact that the hero is doing the exact same thing by trying to forcibly standardize anyone different (Spiderman: No Way Home, anyone?).

I don't think AI is bad. It's just easy to be misused.
Anyone who thinks that AI saves production time has never messed around with AI. While it's good for SFX work (de-aging and filling out crowds), it sucks for more creative works (scripts and actual art); the company ends up not saving time or money because someone needs to come in behind the AI (Forbes actually did an article on this and Shad's video shows the problem (albeit the guy does need to spend more time drawing).   The voice actor contract negotiation was slightly mischaracterized: While game companies can use their voices, the actors need to be compensated for the use.

The bad thing about all these AI movies (both the ones that make it evil and the ones that make it good) is that they all continue to anthropomorphize it, and people are struggling to separate that fiction from reality.  AI includes "artificial" in its name because there is no real intelligence, but, because it is specifically trained to trick people into appearing sentient, too many people are falling for it.  AI isn't dangerous in and of itself, because it will never do beyond what it is programmed to do.  What is dangerous is people's perception of AI, especially in ways that certain people will try to use it.

While I understand that this Propaganda by Disney is to push AI as a means to replace/reduce human needs in production, I still think you did a bit of fear-mongering. AI in itself is not bad, it's a tool, like a hammer, that helps in creating new things at a much more efficient pace. New artists emerge from AI, and new ways of thinking. The problem is not AI, it's the lack of laws and policies around it. I was part of a Bureau with other Computer Scientists and the role is to create laws to protect the Artists and other people against AI (Plagiarism, Job Theft) while still encouraging it. I think educating people on how to use AI and what is ethical is much better than downright saying AI is bad. Especially since it's inevitable as the future comes. Otherwise great video!

My argument with AI is that nobody complains that machines make furniture. I personally don't get the difference.  If the AI stuff is bad,it isn't a threat to humans. If it's good, then why shouldn't it be used? I recently saw youtubers I watch get criticised for using AI thumbnails. So did they get an artist to draw it? No,they just replaced it with a badly edited version. They went from having a good thumbnail to a kinda low quality thumbnail. In all this talk about big companies using AI,I worry that it will discourage smaller groups or individual creators from using AI,which will ultimately lead to worse products. I don't necessarily have the funds to pay an artist to make art or hire voice actors if I'm an indie game maker so should I do it myself and make a worse product or just use the cheaper,faster AI that I feel more comfortable being controlling and nit picky with,as opposed to a human. It's not my fault if someone chooses to be an artist or voice actor so why should I be expected to not use the cheaper tools I have at my disposal?

Not just movies are starting to use AI. I work for a repair company, answering the phone for those wanting to schedule hvac appointments. They recently made us all install this system that uses AI that listens to the conversations and prompts suggested responses, as well as suggested pages for answering customer questions. Even tries to prompt us on trying to sell memberships.  Apparently everyone was required to install it so they can start training it with data. I know it sounds like a bad sci-fi movie but with how tech is going there is a chance some time down the road it will be able to do what I do, just for much cheaper, invalidating a massive chunk of my career/work experience. The thing about AI is that it IS  a useful tool and can be used well, but currently it's being used to trick people and/or being sourced from people without their permission. If the people using AI would just be upfront and honest about it I think it would be less of a problem. Take Vocaloids, for instance. That is a program and synthesizes a singer. A real person gave permission for their voice to be copied and then users and listeners are aware that it is a program and not the real person. However we have AI now that take peoples' voices without their permission and can be used to trick others into thinking they said something they never did, like the example you used trained on your own voice.

I really wish this video mentioned exactly WHY all this AI-generated content is bad, to give further context on why Disney and other major corporations are pushing so much into it.  There is a huge, very real concern, that artists could be out of a job because companies will use AI instead. That high valuable actors and voice actors may not get paid when an AI uses their image or voice. That a company would prefer using ChatGPT instead of hiring a writer.  This isn't a question of moral, of what it's right or wrong, but about the consequences that come from it. The real underlying concern is that there will be less demand for workers as automation continues, a reduction in wages, firing staff for the company to save costs.  The concern is that there will be more people out of a job because of AI. It's a threat to the financial security of many of us, who spent years learning and improving ourselves for this specific career because we loved it, because it's what we wanted to do.  If AI keeps replacing jobs, what happens when every job is automated? What happens to the workers when companies can afford to not have any workers? If no one can or needs to work, how will they afford to live?  We all want what's best for us and for others. We all want to live a good life. AI is scary because someday it can be a major obstacle for that, for the financial security of many of the creative minds of humanity.

A.I is a human assistance tool. it should never outgrow this role. it assists in the creation of content, but it will never be as good as the content. more so inspiration or such. for example: I have a story I write that ends up just being thousands of barely coherent words on a page. I ask Chat-GPT to help make it a coherent script, and it does so. I use it to generate character art because I'm broke and cannot afford an artist commission or draw it myself, and having those characters designed by A.I can help give artists a reference image base to draw their art from.   in my opinion, Creative commons should apply to A.I, all A.I technology MUST be cited and cannot be monitizable at all. so if disney wants to use actors voices as a.i, not only do they need permission, but they can't sell any product using it.  After all, A.I lacks consistency.     note: A.I as a sentient being I fully endorse. if you are gonna program an entire sentient functioning mind, do it. it's like biologically building someone, just more expensive with more investments.  A.I as a tool I fully endorse as well, as long as it's restricted as mentioned above.  BUT A.I as a way to create content I will NOT support in any facet.
